reviewText:
If you're going to read this, then focus. Put a couple of minutes aside. Pay full attention to me, because this isn't just a review. I'm going to pour my heart into this because I feel that's what this game deserves. This isn't just something you can score.

At first, this game's story is exactly like your standard anime, but it very quickly becomes something far greater. In my 32 hour campaign, there wasn't a single second in which I wasn't enjoying the absolute hell out of everything the game had to offer me. The adorable characters, the amazing story, the graphics of all of the spells...there wasn't a single second where I wasn't entertained.

It got to the point where once I reached the end of the game, I wasn't crying just because of the way the story ended, but also because of the very fact that the game is over now. Sure I knew I could do a new game plus, but something about finishing the game was just so heart wrenching. I can't even remember the last time I shed a tear, and I am a rather stoic man, so it symbolizes a lot that this amazingly emotional game managed to make me cry in different ways at the same time.

Somehow, the repetitive combat isn't a bad thing. The spell effects of each and every spell are entertaining and beautiful enough to keep you interested in seeing them forever. Getting experience and skill points is fun no matter what, to the point where even the slightly-mandatory grinding is even fun. That's saying so much.

Perhaps the most touching, is that it's a fully realized PC port. A game built with a JRPG engine has full mouse and keyboard support. Sure it seems like it would be standard for PC ports to have such things, but seeing a lack of mouse control in recent PC ports like DMC: Special Edition, it's hard not to feel grateful that the developers worked so hard to make mouse and keyboard work everywhere in this game. The amount of love they must have for this game must rival mine. And it does not surprise me, because it's extremely easy to fall in love with this game. You will have to practice the keyboard controls a bit (it took me a little bit to find out that Page Up and Page Down helps you aim your spells in combat, and Page Up re-centers your camera when exploring dungeons) but it won't take long, and the game's turn-based nature is very conducive with this control scheme, ensuring you have as much time as you need to figure out how, and where, to aim your spells. Give it a while, and you won't notice any difference in speed from casting a spell at the right position using a keyboard or a controller.

And to top it all off; my girlfriend gifted me this game and all of its dlc's. Even if it wasn't such an amazing game, it would be worth appreciating simply because she got it for me. But it turned out to be my personal game of the year. Deandra, I love you, and I can't thank you enough for giving me this art, and I can't thank Compile Heart and Idea Factory enough for creating it.

reviewText:
If you have played and loved either of the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth games, skip to part B. If you haven't, read on.

A) Fairy Fencer F is goofy, totally nonsense JRPG from Compile Heart, with the least (most?) likeable main character ever. However, because of its cute supporting characters, entertaining (if somewhat grindy) battle system, hilarious (sometimes hilariously bad) dialogue, and genuinely interesting story premise, I had a really difficult time putting it down last night.

So you're Fang, an extremely lazy kid who by total happenstance becomes a Fencer, charged with collecting the Furies (magical weapons fallen to Earth) to unseal the goddess. Sounds simple, right? Well... not really. You also have the option to unseal her opponent, the Vile God (but who would do that, right?!) So the game doesn't seem to mind giving the player options in this regard, and it seems to be set up for multiple endings.

To  keep it short and sweet, if you're a fan of well made JRPGs, cute things and mixed humour, there is no reason in the world you shouldn't like this. The port runs extremely well (*cough* Arkham Knight *cough*), so go ahead, pick it up and give it a try. The worst thing that could happen is you don't like it and refund it. BUT WHY WOULD YOU DO THAT?!


B) Get it. More of the same moe awesomeness and cheesy humour, with a male main character (more character variety in general.) Almost identical battle system. A little less refined, but it works well. You'll love it.

reviewText:
I'll be brief as possible with this review since this game has been out for some time already on the PS3. You should really look at those reviews on the game content itself.

What I really want to focus on is why this is a good PC port and why you should consider it.

+ It's reasonably priced (at launch was $14.99)
+ DLC is $0.99 a piece and totally optional to the core game
+ It runs at 1920x1080 (1080p) at 60FPS without issue
+ Works with my older gamepad just fine (Logitech Cordless Rumblepad 2)

Now I can't say whether or not the core game itself is your cup of tea; but I do want to say that many of the technical issues that plauged the PS3 version shouldn't be present here. At worst, it's a cleaned up smooth running PS3 port. At best, it's a JRPG that at least feels like it belongs on the PC unlike other half-♥♥♥ attempts recently from other publishers/developers.

For PC port  For PC it works perfectly fine for me at 60 FPS and no bugs.
For people who expierence low FPS on windows 8.1 i suggest you to update it to windows 10 beacuse after doing that it increase my FPS from 43 to 60.

A brief overview of the Story A long time ago there was a conflict between a goddess and a evil god. The two deities didn’t fight directly, but created a large number of special weapons imbued with their godly energy, each containing the life force of a fairy for others to use. Eventually, these powers sealed each other and the power vanished from the world. Going into modern times, warriors that wield the powers (Furies) are known as Fencers."
Fairy Fencer F places you in the role of Fang reluctant hero that is more interested in his next meal

reviewText:
Just finished my first playthrough! Takes about twenty hours, but that's if you rush it JUST a little - I was rather underlevel for the last boss, but JUST scratched by at low level 30. Only just, and that's with the DLC items.

+ The good +
~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ Fun battle system.
+ Great OST
+ Characters are rather funny and some can get a little deep.
+ Story was pretty decent, with some decent twists here and there!
+ Transformations are pretty cool and make you feel powerful!
+ The skill system is nice and putting in effort feels VERY rewarding!

- The Bad -
~~~~~~~~~~~~~
- Revisiting almost all the dungeons, at least ONCE or twice in the game
- Game can be short and beaten rather quickly; under twenty hours
- Varity of item crafting looks good, but I didn't feel pushed to make use of it


In the end; the game is aimed towards those that like anime like things, with the game at times feeling more like a VN than a game itself. It's a JPRG that's fun to play!

TL;DR - If you see the game on sell and want a decent game to play? Get this. Very much worth it.

reviewText:
The PC port of Fairy Fencer F is a great PS3 port unlike other ports that are 1:1 ports without PC exclusive features. Resolutions up to 4K and possibly higher are supported! There are options to enable AntiAliasing in the FairyFencer.ini not only that but it can run at any FPS your pc can handle so those with 144Hz monitors can change the 60fps cap to 144 via the FairyFencer.ini located at the games root. Older video cards can disable shadows and effects to gain an fps boost (also found in the .ini).

Performance aside the game is quite fun to play! The translation wasn't screwed over, the combat system is great and the characters actually develop as the story goes. I have played through this game 8 times and exp grinded like hell and i'm still not burned out!

Overall this was a hell of a good game. Would I recommend? What kind of silly question is that? Of course I recommend!!

reviewText:
I have played and platinumed Fairy Fencer F on the PS3, and this review is based on my playthrough of that, and what I've seen for this port's optimization. I'll edit the review if I see the need to as I playthrough the game.
This is going to be very simple pros and cons to get straight to the point, and make some comaprisons with Hyperdimension Neptunia, since that's what a lot of the people buying into this are expecting.

Characters Fang, Eryn and Tiara are fantastic comedy-centered characters. However, these are the only characters that will give you the same feel as Neptunia. Not only that, but every other playable character is almost completely insignificnt. (Minus a betrayal or two.) The voice acting is fantastic; both Japanese, and English. The art and character sprites are much better than in Neptunia.

Dungeons The dungeons aren't copy pastes of eachother. That's right, did going through the same exact landscape OVER, AND OVER in Neptunia get on your nerves? You don't have you worry about it for this. Some of the dungeons are far more expancsive as well. Regardless, however, many still aren't the most visually appealing.

Combat Almost a copy-paste of Neptunia's system. There are some differences, such as the tension gauge, which is used to Fairize (Essentially the characters transformation, like that CPU forms in Neptunia.). You do not equip weapons, because each weapon is bound to the character it is equips on. Instead you power up your character with WP you gan through battle.

Grinding The grinding in Fairy Fencer F is much worse than Neptunia. Although the game does not pose very much difficulty, you'll still be killing the same enemies OVER AND OVER to amass WP, to power up your weapons. WP is earned maybe 2-3 per battle, and is used to dictate your weapons Physical attack Power, to its Range, special attacks, normal combo attacks and even the amount of hits it gets in a combo. It also gets to the point where a single power up can cost 1000 WP. So get ready for the grind train when you go to play this.

Story It's pretty generic for jRPG games. Sealed dieties that split their power in the past. Hero finds a fragment" of the power and continues on a journey to unseal the "goddess"
date: while the badguys try to unseal the "demon lord". You'll basically fight one badguy at a time sent by the enemy organization until you reach the end of the game. All threee ending are lackluster. Once again
hoursPlayed: and Compile Heart's characters that make the game.\n\nOptimization They overlayed the buttons for default keyboard use; which they didn't do for Re;Birth's steam release. This makes it much easier to get used to the mapping. There's always full controller support as well if you're still having trouble. There's much more mouse support than Neptunia. YOU CAN MOVE AROUND WITH THE MOUSE. REVOLUTIONARY. I haven't had too many FPS issues
voteText: as I did with Re;Birth (Mainly Sister Generation) but

votesHelpful: so I don't have much experience with FPS issues in the first place. Most of the DLC comes with the product. Of course

reviewText:
Its good, a traditional JRPG with a few gimmicks such as a heavy visual novel approach (Tears to Tiara 3, Hyperdimension for example) and  extremely flashy encounters that you'de normally see on consoles.  Some of the best parts of this game, despite the combat being simplistic is how pretty it looks.  All of the spells, and abilities have their own little cutscene and  all actions happen snappily and quickly. The audio is good, the English dub is liveable but the Japanese dub is better (especially if you understand things that don't translate well).

The story is anime influenced and is more on the silly/moe side of that.  It is a fun story, nothing too serious and  slightly cliche at points.  The story is self aware of just how cliche it can feel, and sometimes makes fun of itself.  There is a deeper undertone but I doubt it'll matter.  Now get the boy his damn /FOOD/!  It is more cohesive then most straight up Visual Novels, but there isn't much choice as it only has 3 possible endings without much deviation in your activities.

As a PC port, it works perfectly.  And really that is the #1 criteria for any game that exists. The game only has resolution settings, including borderless mode.  That is pretty much all there is for PC related enhancements, everything looks crisper and cleaner then the console version so I can't really find anything to complain about this.   Its a fast game, the FPS feels smooth, the action is smooth.

Overall it is a fun game to play, especially at its current price of $15.  Its a competent port, and is pretty to look at.  Its a bit easy, so you won't enjoy this game if you want a challenge.  Nor will you want this game if you're looking for a deep engaging story that will make your brain think on all cylinders.  But if you want something light hearted and easy to digest then this games story will pass for you.  Thumbs up~!

reviewText:
I can't say this is one of the better JRPGs on Steam, given that most JRPG players demand a certain level of depth and character development in their games, but nonetheless I would still recommend it.

It's a very well designed game, in that all the art, animations, menus, and customizations are well polished. Most people that catch me playing it think it looks really cool, and you get that feeling while playing it too. The dialogue is often funny and the characters will even surprise you, but it's still as a whole a kind've hollow experience.

It's easy to become overpowered, the monsters and environments aren't very diverse, the story is pretty generic with no real revelations or challenges, and sometimes the characters seem bored and flippant about everything that going around, not to mention the bad guys aren't very interesting or intimidating. Depth is certainly not the games forte, but I didn't end up minding it too much.

It's actually kind of nice to have nothing invested sometimes, the characters almost seem aware that they're in a silly JRPG and the developers put in plenty of missables/grinding/extras for people hoping for more of a challenge. There's so much fun small stuff packed in, like all 39 of the furies you can collect having something to say about current events, or buffing/debuffing areas to grind more efficiently. Lots of cool ideas with the battle system, even though it mostly doesn't matter since you can blow away anything in the main game after level 40. Even though the characters aren't going to have any complex problems or feelings, they are all colorful and enjoyable, I ended up liking everyone and having a hard time choosing my party.

If you really dig playing RPGs and don't mind a bit of repetivieness and grasping plot points, it's a really fun game. I feel like I've been negative, but I really loved it quite a bit (obviously... my hours)! I stopped playing just to write a positive review, and now I'm getting back to it...

reviewText:
If you've ever played any of the Hyperdimension Neptunia games, you already know what to expect. You can skip reading this and pick it up as you will fit right into Fairy Fencer F.

Fairy Fencer F ditches the futuristic feel of the Hyperdimension games and returns to the more traditional scene. Countryside with shopkeeps and all kinds of taverns. It feels very Atelier-esque. Basically, Hyperdimension Neptunia, but set in the scenery of Atelier Rorona/Atelier Totori.

You play as Fang, a male main character and meet Nep-Nep in red hair and wings Eryn, a fairy that inhabits a weapon. Together you must find 100 other fairies to revive the Goddess and stop the Vile God from destroying the world

...you know, standard JRPG stuff.


While I joke about Fairy Fencer F being Hyperdimension Neptunia in a different setting, FFF actually does a good job in separating itself from HN. Sure there are Nep references here and there (Pudding!) but on the whole, FFF really does feel like it's own universe.

If anything, the game sort of feels too short. It's about half of Hyperdimension Neptunia. Half the party members, half the dungeons, half the items and half the length to beat a playthrough.

One thing FFF beats Neptunia over though, is a fully fleshed out combo system for attacks. While Special Attacks are rather limited (Each Character has around ~5 of these) the standard attacks can be combo'd with an insane amount of styles. Your weapon will automatically shift from a sword, to a gun, to a scythe or arrow depending on how you set up your chain attacks. Also, the EXE gauge returns in the form of Fairize". Build up the gauge and Fairize to do double the damage.

Another thing that FFF does uniquely
date: is the Fairies themselves. I really liked this. You can assign any fairy you have to any of your party members
recommended: and each Fairy has different stats to boost the character with. Equip a Fairy that gives you bonus Fire damage to a member who specializes in Fire attacks to do insane damage.\n\nI wish there were more fairies though -- the game says you have to find 100 fairies to revive the goddess
hoursPlayed: yet I believe there are only around ~45 fairies you can actually obtain. They all range from badass dragons and monsters to cutesy fox girls and buff tough-talking dudes. They each have their own charm (they are all fully voiced too!) and I just loved collecting all of these different kinds of fairies.\n\nI would have liked to of had an option to take fairies from defeated foes. Several enemies and baddies had some very fantastic and cute looking fairies that I would of liked to add to my roster instead of them just dying. Yeah sure the dude is dead
voteText: but I can take his cute fairy and make her my companion can't I? ;_;\n\nI hope Fairy Fencer F gets a sequel. I'd love to play another one. It has it's own unique charm that's different from Hyperdimension Neptunia.  Heck
helpfulPercent: you know what would be even greater? A Hyperdimension Neptunia x Fairy Fencer F crossover. YES PLEASE.\n\nEryn best girl."

reviewText:
Step in the shoes of Fang, a lazy young man who, through the miracle workings of destiny, becomes a fencer, charged with gathering furies and removing the seals of the Goddess, who has been at war with the Vile God for centuries, both of which are now sealed away in another world.

Fairy Fencer F is a typical JRPG, that means there’s quite a bit of talk, and a bit of grind. It’s also a console port, and as such, it has some peculiarities.

Fairy Fencer F is basically a turn-based RPG with beautiful anime-styled art. When you’re not dungeon-crawling, you have a view of static maps and Visual Novel styled conversations with other characters. When you are dungeon crawling you get those same anime characters in 3D view. You only see the party leader until you enter a battle, and you can only choose so many of your friends to battle with you.
Battles are turn based, but not static. You can move freely around a predesigned circular area of reach (and sometimes enemies will be outside this area), which gives you a sense of freedom despite the limitation, something move-by-places or only-x-steps type of turn based games don’t give you.

The sound and voices are very nice and very fitting to the whole anime/fantasy theme, and I’m particularly fond of the song used when you use “fairize”; it reminds me lots of the songs in Persona 3 and 4. By the way, did I mention you can choose between English and Japanese voices? Because you totally can. It had my heart right then and there.

Now, I’ll try to explain this as best I can. Basically you play as Fang, a Fencer, that is: a person who can wield Furies, which are weapons that contain fairies that add powers to the weapon/wielder. Your job is to go out and search for more furies - each one you get will grant you a new fairy. You can add these to your own weapon as “resonance” to make it stronger and give you some extra stats. The fairies you’re currently using gain experience along with you and level up. Fairies are also ranked - the rank is used to remove the seals (swords) on the Goddess/God. While the story tells you to remove the Goddesses’ seals, after the tutorial you can choose to remove the Vile God’s seals as well, which is a neat touch! Each seal removed successfully adds different boosts/stats to the fairy used to remove it, which in turn adds it to you if it’s the one you’re using as resonance. Fairies that aren’t currently being used in your weapons can be stabbed as their fury forms on the world map in order to provide various boosts, buffs and debuffs in the nearby dungeons (for instance, earn more exp, or gold, or drop rate… ). Since you can stab more than one fury into the ground, you can get quite a few boosts while on a single dungeon.

You have combos for physical attacks which you can customize, and you can at a fly switch between three different ones while attacking by simply pressing one key instead of another, all comfortably close by. Because you have so many ways to affect stats and boosts, the system ends up being quite flexible and enjoyable to play with.
It’s a very interesting concept and I feel like I don’t do it justice explaining it thus briefly.

Saving is done through specific spots while inside a dungeon, or at any time within the world/city maps. While in the city you get to speak with a lot of characters and take up quests that can give you some prizes and can also be repeated (indefinitely, as it seems). The quests are fairly typical, but quick to get done, and go along with what rank you are. You can also craft some items to help on your journey. There is some romance in this game.

Because this was a console port, the controls at first can be a bit awkward (for instance, you can’t use esc to exit menus, you must use backspace; you can use the mouse too, but it’s really more of a hassle than using only the keyboard); however, once I grew used to them they were actually very sensibly placed and quite comfortable to use. I ended up using just the keyboard all the time.

I do wish the game was free-roaming rather than turn based, and the fights do get a tad repetitive after a while, making the fighting aspect of the game feel a tad like a grind. However, the story is nice and full of funny moments and the characters are cute and extremely likeable, all of them with their own personalities, doubts and insecurities.

The game really makes you want to collect all the fairies and remove the seals to see what will happen, keeping you hooked with the story. It also offers a New Game Plus + mode upon completion, which I always love but haven’t yet reached. Fairy Fencer F is a delightfully long game (with 30+ hours if you’re playing through just the main storyline, and over a 100 if you’re going for completion), but from what I’ve seen so far I’m confident in recommending this game to everyone who is into JRPGs.

reviewText:
Some first impressions from my first hour of playtime regarding the port and comparability to Hyperdimension Neptunia:

First off, the game runs smooth even on my old toaster card. This is likely due to it being more CPU intensive to begin with, but even then I am seeing no hiccups with my i5-4460 and my HD5750, running Windows 10 Pro x64 - in other words, the game runs smoothly at 60fps (which is the default lock as per the .ini file, but may be unlockable).
There are no in-game graphics options to speak of besides resolution and a fullscreen/windowed/borderless toggle, but then you'll hardly need more, seeing the game's artstyle and heavy reliance on animated 2D backgrounds and sprites. Further graphics settings may be available in the .ini file again, and AA can be forced via your graphics vendor's control panel regardless.
Settings for controls, sound and so on are all there, including manual button remapping for your gamepad (which should help with getting non-standard Xinput pads to work), and Voice, Movie, Effects and BGM volumes have separate sliders, as they should have.

From a gameplay standpoint, the game is close to Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth, which it supposedly shares the engine with. If you've played Neptunia, you'll find it easy to get into the systems, though even after an hour of playtime, there are differences and additions in Fairy Fencer F.

Those differences include the Tension meter that raises/lowers your stats in combat and allows you to transform at a certain point (whereas Neptunia gave you more free reign with transformations), boosting" weapon stats

reviewText:
A nice little JRPG, but nothing that will captivate you and keep you invested for a hundred hours.

It's very light on the story and character developement, and ultimately very generic and full of clichés, common anime tropes and fan service, but it's also very self aware and prone to break the 4th wall, which - combined with pretty decent english voice acting - actually makes for a mildly humorous experience every now and then.

Combat system is ok, but nothing special or innovative either. AND, most importantly :
Battles are EXTREMELY easy.
I'm not talking about it being not challenging enough if you know what you're doing, no, you can literally kill everything in this game with one or two basic attacks. Including bosses, and you always act first. This is even more annoying when the game tells you via cutscenes that the upcoming boss is supposed to be super powerful and all, and then you almost one-shot them on the first turn, at which point the fight is interrupted by another cutscene that shows your characters inexplicably getting the crap beaten out of them. Followed by some Cutscene Power To The Max they throw you back into the fight and you now proplerly one-shot the boss. It's really stupid and happens many times throughout the story.

Enemies do so little damage that it's virtually impossible to lose. I was surprised to see that there was no achievement for getting a game over. which I was only able to get after stacking various damage increasing effects on a dungeon (quadruple damage - for your party and enemies alike) and randomly missing my first attack against a boss.

And if it wasn't clear by now, there is no difficulty slider or anything. At. All.

The dungeon design is acceptable, but eventually reaches the pinnacle of laziness when they send you back in time halfway through the story" and make you go though all the previous dungeons again
date:
with the same enemies and the exact same bosses.



Fairy Fencer F is one of those generic low budget JRPGs that usually get scores around the 55-65% mark.
If you've really already burned yourself out on every other JRPG out there
recommended: you could probably grab this. but if you're playing your games for the story or the battles you're going to be disappointed.\n"

reviewText:
Ever wondered what would happen if Rance met Nep?

After about 9 hours of gameplay I am able to say that this is a great game. I came for the nep, stayed for the story.

You play this lazy character Fang, whom I can see quite reminiscent of my previous anime games. The tsukkomi is real with Eryn, the mecha-cuteness factor is there; this is simply one of those games in which you will enjoy the dialogue so much you could even prefer it over the gameplay. Fang is... scumbag yet a great MC at the same time.

*Basically Rance without raep.

About the smoothness of the game... I run a cheap computer with an integrated Intel HD Graphics 4000 (I'm casual). It's working well on 1366 width, and very well at that. That means if you have a discrete graphics card this game will be perfect.

I personally have no comments about the gameplay. It's great, actually, though I know more than a few games with similar gameplay. I personally like the animation of fairicing (fairizing) though! (No spoilers yet of course)

It now sells for 15 dollars, which is a very good price for a game like this. Don't waste the chance.

reviewText:
Before people start giving me crap for the negative review, I would like to say that these are opinions based solely on my own experience with the game. I don't hate this game, I'm just very disappointed in my experience with it. If anything, I want to like this game more than I actually do. With that said, onto the review.

TL;DR version: A pretty bland game with bland characters, a bland story and bland combat. It's not worth nearly 30€ for this. If you plan to get it, get it while it's at least 50% off.

I came into this game from Idea Factory's Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 and 2, expecting it to be a somewhat more serious but still a lighthearted JRPG. For the most part, I got that. However, as I dug deeper into the game, there were so many different things that got to me that didn't really make my experience any more enjoyable.

My first problem is with the characters. They're not all that interesting, good character development happens mostly for 3 characters only (out of a possible 14) and I found none of the characters to be anything special. For example, Fang is a selfish guy who just wants to live his life the way he wants but eventually has to mature up to be a hero-type, Tiara is a noble-like character who seems to have a fetish for being verbally degenerated (I'm not kidding, she seems to get these moments of euphoria every time she's called the b-word), Pippin is a walking talking cat pillow that's supposed to resemble something of a veteran noble or something... Then there's Harley... I'll let you guess what she's all about with the help of this link. In short, none of the characters have anything that makes them especially interesting (other than a few small quirks), which makes them kind of bland in my eyes.

Without spoiling the game, the plot doesn't really hold water for me either. The objective is stated at the very start of the game: Collect furies
recommended: you win". Pretty much towards the end of the game the objective stays the same

reviewText:
As a lover of turn-based RPG, I was looking to test the waters in the JRPG sub-genre. Seeing this game on sale for 50% off and newly released, not to mention the great reviews of the game on console, I decided to take the leap.

Pros:
- Combat system is fantastic and a change of pace from your typical turn-based RPG
- Unique Story / Protagonist
- Great character customization in terms of combat and accessories
- Good intro / tutorial
- English Voice acting is actually pretty good
- The port is well done and can be run on any computer without issue (I'm playing on a Macbook just fine)

Cons:
- No difficulty setting (this is a personal issue though I feel)
- Characters break the fourth wall / goofy (can be a turn off for some, story-wise)

Definitely worth the buy for any new / veteran JRPGers. Although I will advise to stay away from the item pack / fairy DLCs as they ruin the game. I purchased those and after realizing they were available from level 1 and made the game stupid easy, I haven't equipped them.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F is a nice little mixture of visual novel and RPG style game mechanics and combat. You play as Fang, a guy who ends up acquiring a Fury without realising the responsabilities that come with it. Furies are swords left on the planet long ago after a battle between the Vile God and the Goddess, and each of them has a fairy inside. The fairy inside your Fury, Eryn, explains to you that the Fury is only able to use to those who are destined to fulfill the wish of its fairy. She then explains to you that she wishes you find 100 Furies in order to awake the Goddess. This is where your journey begins.

Gameplay overview:
We could say that the gameplay of this game is divided into two very different genres. For me, the real meat of the game is the combat, which despite being somewhat repetitive, allows for a lot of different approaches due to the variety of abilities that you can use. Combat is turn based, and in each turn you move your character freely inside a circle and must get within range of the enemy in order to attack. If you get close to this outer circle you can attempt to escape the battle. You’ll be able to to switch between Fencers on the fly, once you have more on your party, but doing so while in combat will end your turn. As you acquire more Furies, you’ll also gain access to more fairies which you can use to increase your stats and get hold of more abilities. Not only that, but acquiring more Furies allow you to start working your way to free the Goddess, or the Vile God if you prefer, and will also enhance your fairy abilities.

The other part of the game plays pretty much like a kinetic visual novel, in which the player has no actual impact on the conversations and outcomes. That said, I find the dialogue to be rather amusing, if somewhat uninspired. If you’re looking for a deep story, great plot and memorable characters you probably won’t find that here. Still, I find the dialogue rather funny with the ocasional joke here and there, and most of the characters behave like teenagers which gives the game a less serious tone. Also, most of the main story dialogue is fully voice acted, while optional conversations are not.

You’ll be spending a lot of your time revisiting Zelwinds the main city in the game. Here you can go to different places and talk with random people. You’re also able to buy and sell items, get side missions (kill & fetch quests) and acquire information about the whereabouts of the next Fury. Still, the city feels somewhat lifeless since everything happens through a menu screen. There is no depth to the places and to the different people you find there, they are pretty much there just for the sake of being there, and this made me care less about the actual game world.

There is also a world map where you can go to various different locations, such as dungeons. There you’ll battle enemies and find varied items. Inside dungeons you can move freely and see enemies wandering, and if you manage to get in close and attack them you’ll trigger an ambush and the battle will start, thus allowing to attack first. Of course, if the enemy gets the drop on you, you’ll be the one getting ambushed. This is probably where I spent most of my time, grinding in dungeons to level up my characters and fairies, doing side quests, collecting items and selling them so that I could afford potions, etc. If you’re not too fond of grinding, you might have a hard time later on with some enemies.

Pros:Good looking anime style visuals
Tons of customization and unlockables
Great soundtrack - featuring pieces from different musical genres
Fun turn-based combat - with tons of different abilities
Cons:Repetitive dungeons
Lifeless locations & bland NPCs
Final verdict:
If you’re looking for a memorable story and unique characters you might want to steer away from this, unless you’re a hardcore fan of the Neptunia games and the likes of Idea Factory. The story might be interesting for some people until a certain point, and most of the character reactions are rather predictable. Still, if you’re looking for a solid RPG experience with a very robust turn-based combat system this might be something right up your alley. There are tons of unlockables for you to track down, and if you’re into completing side quests there are always some for you to do. Thus, revisiting old dungeons will always yield some kind of reward.

Overall, I’m enjoying my time with Fairy Fencer F, despite its flaws. If you’re unsure it is worth the full price, grab it on sale. Chances are, if you’ve read this far, you’ll most likely enjoy it.

reviewText:
As I write this the game is on sale for 15 dollars and I'd say it's a pretty good deal.

First off, it doesn't have any launch problems at all for me and it plays perfectly on windows 7. The Xbox3460 controller can be chosen as the input device in the configuration.

As far as the game itself goes, I like the following things:
You can skip spell/attack animations at the touch of a button.
Battle system is quick and fast. Battles with weak enemies don't drag on forever due to lengthy animations.
Characters are fairly likeable.
There's plenty of boobs going around.
The graphics are very colorful.
It's easy to use the camp menu to find what you need to.
The skill system is fun and easy to learn. Gain WP to learn skills that are prerequisites for better skills.
What I don't like:
Characters usually have one modified portrait at most to represent their speech, and the game tries rather comically to make it seem like they're doing things, such as pushing an ally aside by having one picture shove another.

This is obviously a fairly low budget game. A lot of art assets are re-used, like entire dungeons.

The story is just the typical JRPG thing. A reluctant hero saves the world to restore the goddess of light so she can defeat the dark Vile God. It would have been nice if the joking scenario Harley claimed was actually the real story instead of this.

The combo editing system makes little sense. When I go to the menu, I can't change anything even after learning a variety of skills for a character. Either this is a bug or the developers decided to introduce the system too early in the story (eg. it's something advanced I can't actually make use of yet).

reviewText:
-SHORT SPOILER FREE REVIEW-

Before receiving this game from a friend, I was already aware that the developer of the game was the infamous 'compile heart', renowned for their 'waifu simulator neptunia' series. So going into Fairy Fencer F, I was expecting a game with a half-arsed story, terrible game mechanics and a million anime girls. Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the Male-to-Female character ratio is, rather than 100% female, closer to 1-1. There is almost an equal number. So the game delivers in providing a diversity of characters. tl;dr FFF character design > HDN

Fairy Fencer F is rich with dialogue, dialogue which comes in all forms. So far in fact, that as you collect 'furies' throughout the game and the corresponding fairies to each fury that are displayed in your inventory, each will have something to say on every topic in the game, it's endless fun to sit and browse through your fairies and learn each fairy's individual thoughts and point of view. The comedic value of the game is significant, I was provided with a significant portion of laughter. There are feels, and the soundtrack matches the artwork and tone of the game almost spot on.

A significant flaw in FFF is the difficulty level, this game is far too easy, it doesn't take a lot of skill to play, which is fine for the most part with JRPGs since they are mostly story-driven (You only have to look at final fantasy to see that). However, it wouldn't hurt to throw in an actual challenge once in a while.

All in all the game was pretty good, I grew attached to some of the characters, I was pleasantly surprised by FFF, I was going into this game expecting to be utterly disappointed by a subpar game, drenched in 'waifus'. HOWEVER, as was made clear in my review, this game was far from that.

Gameplay - 7.5/10
Character design / development - 8/10
Story - 8/10
Soundtrack - 9/10
Artwork - 9.5/10

Room for improvement, but a fantastic game!

reviewText:
TL;DR: Mixed feelings about this game. Enjoyable characters and some mechanics make it interesting and worthwhile but a lot of other aspects are flawed.

Story:
Fairly generic, guy finds sword, has to save the world (revive the goddess, greater good) while fighting evil organization that wants to reshape the world to its needs (revive the evil god, for personal gains). The plot twists aren't great but still manage to keep the story going.

A first playthrough without grinding too much should take you around 20-25 hours, which is fairly decent.

The story/interactions are displayed in a visual novel form, same as Neptunia games, so it involves a lot of reading.
Thankfully the characters are quite fun, starting with the lazy anti-hero main character, making the dialogues entertaining (and there's a lot of it).

The main goal during the story is to acquire Furies to free the goddess. Each Fury gives you some additional main stats and bonuses (power, xp, protection, regen...). A bit later they also get world-shaping modifiers which allow you to alter dungeons (new and old). Those changes vary from bonus attack/defense to increased rewards or ennemies change, but almost every modifier also has a penalty: a +10% physical attack bonus will have a -10% magical attack penalty for instance.

Combat system:
If you're familiar with Neptunia combat system it's quite similar: Basic attacks/Skills/Magic, plus a Fairize mode (a tension gauge fills during battle and then lets you transform in a more powerful version of yourself and gives you access to 1-2 utlimate attack) and an additional skill for each character.

The basic attacks use a combo system, the more you advance in the game the more consecutive attacks you'll do. It's a very important aspect especially early on. You can chose to create fancy combo with aerial attacks or just chain your most powerful ones, it won't change much, which is sad.

While it seems good on paper you probably won't use everything in battle. The game is quite easy and with Fury world-shaping you'll adjust your playstyle to a more efficient way.

Equipment:
Your weapon is your main Fury, and you can't change it, only upgrade it using WP rewarded by defeating enemies, which leaves you with only 2 slots of equipment: armor and ring. It's not much, and when you consider the stat increases they provide it's even less.

Upgrading your weapon will give your more stats, combo, Fairize power, range, and skills. So it'll cost you a lot of WP to fully upgrade all your characters.

Armor and ring represent about 10-15% of your total stats, maybe more at the beginning but it kinda kills the need to upgrade often or to get the best armor which will give you 10% more than the previous best on the 10% total stats of your character... so maybe hours of farming for a 1% stat increase, great.

You are also able to equip" a secondary Fury
date: giving you bonus stats and some other ability boosts. Those equipped Furies will level up
recommended: unlocking more boosts and increasing your stats even more.\n\nThe other way to improve your characters stats is to complete challenges. Each one has a wide variety of challenges: control for X minutes
hoursPlayed: kill X enemies
voteText: attack X times... It's nice until you realize it's impossible to complete unless you spend hundred of hours grinding. So by playing normally you'll have a few bonus stats on the characters you use most
helpfulPercent: but nowhere near their full potential.\n\nAnd if you bought the DLC increasing the maximum level to 999
votesHelpful: well there's no new gear
votesTotal:
only what you get by leveling up.

Sidequests/occupations:
The basic sidequests system is ranked quests: in the town bar you'll be able to pick basic kill/fetch quests depending on your rank. After completing a certain number of quests at your current rank you'll have access to a unique quest to increase your rank
votesFunny: two of those quests can take up to a few hours to complete while the others take a few minutes. But at least it's totally optional
commentsCount: I can't think of any worthwhile reward except an achievement for achievement Rank S  and 1 rank B quest in NG+ for a Fury\n\nThe game being based on Furies
column16: you'll find some quests telling you where to find some Furies (16 of them) in previously visited dungeons. Those quests have 2 bad aspects: the "previously visited dungeons" aspect
column17: and the fact that they appear for a limited time
column18: some right after you enter a dungeon but before finishing it (easy to miss if you don't leave a dungeon right from the start)
column19: and some right after finishing a dungeon (hard to miss). If you miss one
column20: you'll have to get it in the next playthrough
column21: and managing to do all 16 in the same playthrough rewards you with a bonus character.\n\nThere's also a bonus dungeon
column22: a tower which gains 1 floor for each of your Fury involved in world-shaping

column24: and some items.\n\nIn the Shop you'll have access to the Synthesis system

armors and items in the shop are enough and except early in the game you'll never lack money to buy your items instead of using the synthesis system.


NG+:
Since the game has 3 endings (more like 3 variations on the last 5 dialogues)

DLCs:

The "Surpass your limits" DLC will give you eveything content related: 3 more maps (copies of already existing maps with high level enemies)

I probably forgot some other points  but it's already quite lenghty so:

Conclusion:
I enjoyed my first playthrough

it's quite grindy.

So basically I'd recommend it as long as you don't plan on going too deeply into it. For around $8 on sale it's worth the entertaining 20h you'll get out of it.

reviewText:
Pros+It feels like playing better Hyperdimension Neptunia
+The storyline is interesting
+The game succesfully combines fun, humour and grimdark storyline
+Weapons with talking fairies inside of them which allow you to transform
+Everything major to the storyline is fully voiced
+You can access voicelines of characters in menu of the game which allows easy voice sampling
+Different ways to customize your own character playstyle via huge variety of powerups and combos
+The theme with revival of the goddess and the vile god is interesting
+The art and character design is great
+The music is quite good and fits the gameplay
+Some characters have great concepts
+FAIRIZE

Cons-Bosses. A lot of them are simply unfair towards the player by having tons of hp and dealing more than enough damage to corner you in a heal-or-die combat style which sooner or later leads to the death of your party. You can simply overcome the difficulty of these combats by leveling just one or two levels but bosses still stay tanky, they just deal less damage. What differs bossfights from each other is the amount of HP each boss has.The last dungeon of the game literally made me spam just two buttons because even if bosses dealt ridiculously low amount of damage, they were too tanky and it took way too much time for each one to kill it. It was really dissapointing way to finish a gameplay i really enjoyed.
-Questing system is boring and feels useless
-Dungeons might be considered as empty

SummaryDespite of the flaws i mentioned, Fairy Fencer F is a great game. I really enjoyed these 20 hours i put into finishing it and i would love to spend more time with it. I am not dissapointed with it yet i feel like it could be slightly better. I totally recommend this game for everyone who enjoyed any of Hyperdimension Neptunias, because it is pretty much the same game, just a lot better.

8/10

reviewText:
I have recently completed this game so i can say this

Pro's --
-Good fast paced turn based battle system (Comparable to FFX's battle system)
-Fun memorable characters and interesting story
-Lengthy story line with multiple choices and sub missions
-In depth character customization with custom move sets / combos
-Multiple characters and costumes
-Great voice acting, consistent throughout the entirety of the game!
-Has a new game+ with multiple side quests!
-Controller + Keyboard and mouse friendly with re-mapable keys

Con's --
-Alot of 2D custscenes, not so many 3D Cutscenes (This may come down to preferance)
-It seems the abilites become useless late game as your combos rack up way more damage so you'll find yourself spamming the A button alot
-Recolored enemies, they seem to reuse alot of the enemy models in the game
-Repetitive battle cutscenes (watching the fairization animation 272 times per playthrough becomes a bit annoying)

All in all i rate this a 7.8/10 It's a solid RPG and has some great replay value

reviewText:
THE WAIFU WARS
PART 03: FAIRY FENCER F

The exams are over. You breathe a sigh of relief
as you close your eyes on the couch, with the
erratic weather outside  shifting from rainy to
sunny, as if in sync with Summer-Rain's own
name and temperament. You glance over to your
phone and thumb through, seeing Mrs. Novocaine's
message from the time of Melody's Escape.

Wondering why she wanted to talk suddenly, you
open and see a long message about how so much
has changed for her and she wishes to try to
reconnect with you, and that she might have made
a terrible mistake. You turn off your phone's screen,
disgusted. Booting up your computer, something
greets you on the store page with petticoats,anime
and swords.

FAIRY FENCER F.

Raising an eyebrow, you click 'buy'. Minutes later,
you're in a land of sword-and-sorcery with a vague
hint of technology, and as you progress through the
surprisingly riveting and engaging story, guides and
walkthroughs describe how Fairy Fencer F has links
to the Hyperdimension Neptunia games.

The story, in all its bright technicolor anime glory,
is more than serviceable, with a healthy selection of
waifus who serve as weapon upgrades (!), so much
so that you find yourself lost in the semi-open world
as well. You explore the world as the selfish slacker
Fang, 'duped' to become a Fencer, a warrior using
waifu-weapons, such as his Fairy-weapon-waifu Eryn.

Along the way, you meet the stunning, highbrow,

reviewText:
I have played plenty of JRPGs that I can't see too much difference between this game and the others.

Pros :
- Distinct, unique cast of characters, with nice interactions between each character
- Plenty of character's customization such as weapon upgrade, skill upgrade, costumes, etc
- Good combat animation makes the battles less boring
- Good overall soundtrack
- Japanese-English voice option
- Skippable conversation, pretty convenient for those who want to retry the game in NG+ for achievements
- Consistent 60fps

Cons :
- Somehow, the world felt really small. 1 city and 14 different dungeons (not including DLCs). Most dungeons only consist of 2-3 floors/stages. You can easily explore the whole dungeon in just a few minutes
- Boring, uninspired dungeons
- Lack of challenge in combat
- Pretty common, forgettable, short storyline

If you are looking for games where you can enjoy the story and character's interaction, you will enjoy this game.
Overall, I give this game 7/10. It's not the best for its genre, but it's still enjoyable.

reviewText:
So here's the thing about Fairy Fencer F. Its one of many modern Jrpgs that focuses more on style than substance. The two minute long video on the store page is testament to this. Its not a game for everybody, but those who like this sort of thing will probably enjoy Fairy Fencer F.

Here's a pro/con list of some things I noticed while playing the game.

Pro:
-The battle system can be very flashy and exciting
-There is lots in the way of equipment, items to keep you scouring the game
-The female characters are pretty hot (Yes its a video game but the characters adequetly represent the image of beauty by which they were designed)

Con:
-The dialogue is terrible. Its just bad. I suppose you might enjoy it if you're a diehard anime fan or teenager. But as someone who prefers dialgue that is both well-written and engaging I found this to be unbearable.
-The main character is on-par with the most annoying characters in Jrpg history (right up there with Squall and Tidus)
-There is little in the way of exploration or engaging interaction with the world. You pick an area, go into a dungeon, deal with random cutscenes filled with nonsequitor dialogue then head back to the hub screen. There are no towns, no npcs living in the world, no depth or quirkiness to establish the world as anything more than the 2D backdrop for all the fluff and nonsense this game calls a story.

I'd keep playing this game if I had nothing else to play ONLY because the combat can be mildly enjoyable in short bursts. It is ABSOLUTELY not worth the retail price. Even at 70% off (8.99) I'm hesitant to recomment a purchase. I'd say get this ONLY if you're a wild fan of the waifu anime girls, 14 years old, and struggle getting into games with deep and engaging plotlines.

reviewText:
Indroduction
Fairy Fencer F is a turn-based, action, role-playing game loaded with charming characters. The action takes place in a world where a God and Goddess were in a fight to the death. Their terrible struggle left a fantastic assortment of powerful weapons littering the landscape. You will find not everyone who tries has the ability to wield these relics. It is only those who are worthy of them that can pull them free. Fencers wield these weapons with the assistance of the fairy that resides within the weapon. For once, you are not really saving the world. At the beginning, there really is no peril that a hero/heroine must raise to defeat. In fact, the protagonist of this game isn’t even really a hero at all.

Gameplay
The game is a mixture of a visual novel and an action role-playing game. The story is driven by discussions the playable characters hold as well as their interactions with the NPCs. During the discussions, a static image of the characters is on screen. To emphasize which character is doing the talking, that particular character will have an animated mouth. Emotions are conveyed through a mixture of symbols and facial expressions. If the characters are having a story based discussion, it will be fully voice acted. If it is a random conversation, it will generally be just text on the screen. This works quite well although I do prefer the voiced sections over the just text sections.

When in town you simply select between the various options and you enter into the related screen. You do not need to walk to the item shop or inn when you arrive at the town. This is handy because it saves you from having to remember where each place is and having to run back and forth between them constantly, but I still prefer to have explore-able towns. Dungeons are thankfully free to explore when you get to them. The world map is simple to navigate, it shows places you have already opened and explored. It also conveniently has your next destination(s) flagged on the map as well as where any events or sub-events may be taking place.

Dungeons are where you are going to spend most of your time (outside of dialogues between characters). You are free to roam around as you please. Monsters can be seen wandering around and you have the option to fight them or attempt to avoid them. If you choose to fight them, you can attempt to get a preemptive strike by swinging your weapon right before the battle screen is triggered. If successful, all your characters will get a chance to strike the enemy first. If you fail or if the enemy sneaks up on you, you will be the one ambushed giving the enemies the chance to strike first. Just walking into an enemy will put your characters and enemies in that standard cue to fight. The fight cue is always displayed and lets you know who will get their turn next. When you are controlling a character in combat, you have a movement circle. You can move anywhere in that circle before you take your action. Once you take your action, your turn ends and the next in cue gets to take theirs. Since each weapon type and ability has its own range and effective arcs, it makes for a nice variety when playing.

The game has a lot of customization options available to you. While you can’t change your weapon, you can reconfigure it so it changes into a different type of weapon during combat. You are given free choice of what armor and accessories you want to wear as well as your secondary fairy. To make up for the fact you can’t change your weapon, you are given weapon points after battles. These can be spent on how you want to customize the weapon and your related weapon abilities. If you prefer to do a lot of simple physical attacks, that is great. You can set yourself up that way. Do you prefer getting really high combo scores? Well you can buy new combos too. There are a ton of customizations options and luckily you are not locked into your decisions as taking one of the ability does not preclude you from taking a different one later. With enough grinding, you can max out everything for every character.

Fairies make this game more interesting. They do that in three ways.  The first is the fact that when your Tension gauge fills (fills when you do damage or takes damage, but reduces when you miss or heal yourself), you gain the ability to merge with your weapon’s fairy and become much more powerful. Another way the fairies are interesting is that you can acquire new ones as you play. While you can never swap out your main fairy (fused to your weapon) you can swap out your secondary fairy. You can customize the abilities of the secondary fairy to some degree as well. When you acquire a new one, if you equip it, it will level up and gain new abilities. You can also merge it with one of the sealed weapons found impaling the fallen God and Goddess that I mentioned earlier. By merging it, you gain new abilities for the secondary fairy. The third way they are interesting is the fact that you can stick a fairy imbued weapon into the ground to “shape the world” using the shaping abilities of the fairy. This changes up how dungeons work as well as adds extra levels to a tower in the game. By sticking the shaping weapon into the ground, you will get positive and negative effects that will change how the dungeon will play out. You may get extra experience while doing the dungeon, but you will take more damage from magical attacks. It might even change the enemies in the dungeon making it feel a little different when you go through it.

The story and characters in this game diverge a little from the standard clichés for this type of game as well. Instead of being a band of heroic figures rallying to save the world, you have a band of misfits each doing it for their own personal and selfish reasons. The protagonist of the game doesn’t even want to do it. He just pulled a sword out of the ground because someone told him it would grant him any wish he could think of. All he wanted to wish for was a nice meal. He accidentally became linked to the fairy in the sword who then forced him to go on the quest because she has amnesia and wants the other fairies to help her remember her past. Another Fencer is out for her own personal gains and is really full of herself. Another is just studying fairies… you get the idea. None of them are actually real heroes! That makes this game much more fun than the cliché, “let’s save the world from evil” shticks of other RPG games.

Overall, it’s another enjoyable Idea Factory game. If you like the story telling, humour and fan service found in their other games, such as the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, you will likely enjoy Fairy Fencer F as well. If you are looking for a fun dungeon crawler style RPG that has zany characters, by all means give Fairy Fencer F a go.

Pros:It’s long and made longer by having to continue the game in New Game Plus to actually beat the game fully
A lot of customization options including cosmetic changes to the characters
Fun characters that all feel like they do have their own personality. Even the NPCs don’t feel bland or generic
Good use of music
From the drawn visuals of the characters in the discussion scenes to the models used in the dungeons, the game looks good
Not the typical save the world from the bad guy story
Each dungeon feels unique, it isn’t just the same basic enemies and layout rehashed every time

Cons:

DLC make you over-powered if activated too early which might ruin the fun and challenge
Protagonist makes it hard for a person on a diet. (He constantly talks about food)

reviewText:
This is one of those games where you wish you could forget, just so you can experience it first-hand again.

I've ever rarely played J-RPGs, but when I played this game, I was truly in love with it. If you're a fan of J-RPGs and romance anime, you'll surely love this game. TL;DR down below.

Throughout the entire game, you are given a good amount of characters to choose from with more in the later parts of the game. As you progress further into the story, a bit of farming may be needed as enemies become more and more tough to deal with, but as a J-RPG it was already expected. The mechanics of the game maybe a bit tacky and confusing at first, but eventually it becomes easier as you continue to play.

Now, the story was probably one of the best stories I've ever experienced in video games. Each part of the dialogue does its job well, when you need to be happy or laugh, you are met with corny jokes and ridiculous events, but when you need to feel for the characters in the game, you will without a doubt feel the sadness they show. Honestly, as you continue playing the story, you will become immersed and will develop a love for each and every character you play as. Hell, maybe you'll love some characters who you don't even play as.

Next, the replayability potential is high as there are four different routes you may choose from and because there is also a new game+ type system where your stats from your previous run will be brought over to your next run and don't worry, the enemies won't get easy because of this.

Finally, if you actually read all the way here, I give my thanks for doing so and for considering to buy this beautiful, funny and amazing game. I was truly surprised by how much I loved playing this game and regretted for not getting it sooner. As a gamer, I know that some people are out here to buy only one game and that there are many games to choose from. Believe me, I had high doubts when I first bought it since I was entirely new to the J-RPG genre in general. But, this game has been a blast to play through and I wish more people could experience it. Idea Factory truly have outdone themselves with this game.

As it stands, I have finished this game and no longer have a purpose to play it once more. Not having a reason to see my favorite characters again, truly made me sad. But, their sequel is coming and I hope it will live up to its predecessor.
I, as an avid gamer, am looking forward to the next sequel Idea Factory is releasing and hope to see my favorite characters once more.

tl;dr: Beautiful, amazing and funny. What more could you ask for?

reviewText:
Writing this review right after I finished one of the 3 endings.

Fairy Fencer F is a really pleasant experience.
The story will drag you in, make you play trough all of it and after you finish it it will leave you asking for more.
I must admit that there was not a single moment where i got bored while playing this game. The story was a truly wonderful experience.

The combat aspect in this game is rather challenging if you didn't use the weapons/armor provided by the DLC ( and if you waste your money on cosmetics and not potions or equipment, like i did )
But in most dungeons you will end up spamming basic attacks and heals, at least when fighting against low-tier mobs.
The Boss fights were challenging most of the time and made me think of actually using some sort of strategy and forced me to even prepare for those battles beforehand.

The visuals in this game are what you would expect from a decent JRPG so nothing bad or special to comment on that.

And the last thing to comment on was the character design and development. No one of the characters seemed boring and they each contributed to the story in their own way, which i liked. There weren't any useless party members that you just ignored and never made use of.

Overall this game was a really pleasant experience and I will definitely try to complete the two other endings.

reviewText: This is a difficult one. I played this game for only 1.5 hours - and I got bored to death already! ^^ Obviously, Anime fans seem to like it. And I can see why. But to me, what I saw so far was not very appealing. Dialogue is presented in visual novel style, with solid voice actors. What I disliked about it is how absolutely not serious it is. They try to be funny all the time. They try to be cute. And it has this childish/family friendly touch. This is just not what I want from a RPG. I am not an Anime fan, but I am open to it. There were a few Animes I enjoyed. But I like the more serious ones. Not the cute ones. The story might have been interesting to me, but I just don't like how it is presented in this game. The gameplay doesn't seem to be very special. Standard JRPG turn-based combat, as far as I can tell. It's not bad, but it's also not enough to keep me playing despite the mentioned things I dislike about the game. So while I can see that it's probably a nice game for others, it's just not for me. Even after this short amount of time, I am pretty sure I won't play any more of it.\n\nAnd I am completely aware, that I will most likely get downvoted like crazy here. ^^ But that's ok. The review should reflect my personal opinion. And my opinion is that I just don't enjoy the game. And I am sure there are people out there who would feel the same. So that's why I have to give it a thumbs down. I am sure the game can stand one thumb down, with otherwise 93% positive reviews. ;)

reviewText:
Conceptually, Fairy Fencer F would seem to be a return to the roots of the JRPG genre: a traditionally-styled game with a distinctly Japanese story and aesthetic. Consider the alliteration in Fairy Fencer F’s title, which calls Final Fantasy to mind, or the game’s development team, which includes composer Nobuo Uematsu and artist Yoshitaka Amano, both of Final Fantasy fame. How unfortunate, then, that Fairy Fencer F is no glorious return to the heyday of the JRPG, but rather a strange, distorted effort, terrifically fun in bursts but plagued by unfortunate technical issues.

Fairy Fencer F is the story of young warrior Fang and his fairy partner, Eryn. Fang's excessively cynical and derogatory attitude is likely to grate within mere minutes of starting the game, in which he constantly complains about his new path in life. You see, as the game begins, Fang is told by a shopkeeper that if he is capable of pulling out a strange sword embedded in a rock, he will be granted any wish he desires. All he wants is tasty food (a running obsession that becomes unfunny almost instantly), but, upon yanking out the sword, he is greeted by semi-amnesiac Eryn, told he is a legendary fencer, and asked to free the world's Goddess from her stasis by finding and using Furies, fairies trapped in mythical weapons. Fang’s annoyance at having such a burden suddenly dropped on him is understandable, but his continued whininess and apathy is exceptionally irksome. Eryn is more likeable, though the moment another female appears on the scene she goes into (similarly unfunny) jealous-possessive-angry mode.

Fairy Fencer F's least irritating character.
I soon met Tiara, a stuck-up, bratty fencer who harbors a genre-standard terrible secret. She also doubles as an exposition machine, teaching you about the plane beyond reality where the Goddess and evil deity are sealed and giving you a free inn to recover at--when she's not being bossy and condescending. Notice a theme here? The majority of Fairy Fencer F's cast was ripped straight from the pages of Anime Character Tropes You Can Implement Easily. Suffice to say, it takes a fair amount of time before a truly likeable character joins the troupe. Certain party members become more tolerable as time goes on, but it's hard to shake those awful first impressions.

Layers of Fear Announcement Trailer
Check out this new psychedelic horror game from the Polish developer Bloober Team.
Saddled with a party of people I would have liked to punch in the face given the opportunity, I ventured out into the exploration portion of Fairy Fencer F. Much to my relief, exploration and combat are a fair bit more energizing than watching barely-animated character cutouts complain to each other. Combat is turn-based with positioning elements: You and your enemies move around a small field and trade blows with each other, launching area-of-effect spells and utilizing strategic positioning to your advantage. The basics aren't tough to grasp, and as you earn more weapon points in battle, you can customize your stat boosts and add multi-hitting combo capabilities to your characters' strikes.

This kind of cringe-worthy dialogue is par for the course.
The majority of Fairy Fencer F's cast was ripped straight from the pages of Anime Character Tropes You Can Implement Easily.
A neat addition to the formula is the tension gauge: as characters attack and use skills, their tension increases and multiplies the damage they deal. Once tension reaches a certain point, characters can fairize
date: transforming into quasi-robot-armored fighters with access to special, super-damaging techniques. However, playing overly defensively--using lots of healing items and spells, retreating from enemies, running away from battle--reduces the tension, and if it dips below a certain point, your combat efficacy will suffer. It's a neat system that makes the combat considerably more engaging. It's quite fast-paced, as well--the handy L2 button allows you to skip a lot of long-winded combat animations.\n\nYou can find new dungeons to explore at set points in the story, where you'll find some Furies to collect (along with the fairies that inhabit them and/or possibly another fencer). Once you've got a Fury/fairy combo, you can summon the pair to remove one of the binding blades sealing the Goddess and the Vile God. Doing so upgrades the abilities of the fairy, who can then either be assigned to one of your party members or to a dungeon via a process called world shaping." While the stat bonuses fairies can provide to party members are nothing to be sneezed at (and they also level up through combat)

reviewText:
The Good
- Excellent engine performance.  Solid 60 FPS at 1080p and not buggy.  Other than a little stutter on enemy load on level entry, it's flawless.  Other companies should strive to port games like this.
- Visually beautiful.  Characters, outfits, effects, it’s all really nice to look at.
- Character and skill advancement system has a good ‘hook’ to it to keep interesting.
- Music is wonderful.

The Bad
- Character personalities are extremely 1-dimensional.  There are no characters that I even remotely care for as they are cliché incarnate.
- Level designs are completely uninspired, and at no point do I feel like I’m exploring.  Enemy and item placements make no sense.
- Story is simple and boring.  There’s no sense of tension, which is likely due to the uninteresting characters.
- Combat gets ‘old’ in that it’s a bit grindy.  Battles are solved with generally the same strategy every time, fairize meter resets, and enemy formations are not varied enough.

It reminded me a lot of the Neptunia series.  So, if that’s a series you’d like, you’ll probably like this one.  I'm just sorry to say that it's not for me.  I don't think it's terrible, but it's just below interested to play it".  Better character depth or interesting level design would be enough to push it over the line."

reviewText:
Extremely fun game and an enjoyable storyline if you played the Neptunia series you will enjoy this most likely.  The combat is smooth and easy to learn even though there are multiple things that influence combat.  The combat is also very similar to the Neptunia V or the Neptunia Rebirth series.  The game is not exactly short either my first play through of the game took 33 hours.  The game has 3 different endings which does also increase the replayability of the game.

Unlike in many RPG's you do not change your weapon instead as you play the game you aquire something called weapon boost points, these points allow you to customize your weapons stats increasing it's damage, magic attack, increase physical and magical defense how far your attack range is and couple other things.  With weapon boost points you are also able to get new skills, magic, abilites, and a few other things.

Similar to the Neptunia Rebirth series there is a world shaping option as well which allows you to change mobs or items in dungeons however unlike the Neptunia series there is normally a negative that goes with the positive for example you will gain 30% more exp but you will have 10% less defense.

The characters in the game are all likeable and have personality and over the course of the game you actually see their personalites change which is nice to see.  The english voices are all well done and none seem out of place for the character.

The bad in my opinion

If just following the storyline the game is rather easy.

The game has 3 different endings which is good however there really is no clear indication ever of what path you are on basically if you want the other two endings you will either have to go through it with trial and error or look up a guide.

Other than that there really is no negative I can think of. Fun combat, Lots of customization, Easy to play, Enjoyable storyline, Enjoyable Characters, Good english voice acting, Characters with personality, and fairly long.

reviewText:
This is one of the best Idea Factory RPGs I've ever played since Chaos Wars and Blazing Souls.

I have to admit: Idea Factory's earlier RPGs were enjoyable too, but had too many flaws and unpolished features so that I couldn't recommend any of them as a stand-alone game of a genre. Fairy Fencer F is different in my opinion.

It's a turn-based rpg with a combat similar to Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth series and Mugen Souls. If you played those games you'll probably notice many familiar things.
Fairy Fencer actually has a lot more useful and polished features compared to Neptunia Rebirth series. While the game starts off simple, its core gameplay gradually gains more and more stuff. And I'm not talking about just crafting feature or sub-quests. There are unlockable combos, enemy weaknesses, team-attack system, character-unique actions, fairy card bonuses, etc.

Sure there is still quite a few in-game stuff which makes you wonder 'This could've been so much better if you added X', or 'Why did they not exploit this further?', or even 'This system doesn't make much sense.'
But all in all I wouldn't call it a wasted potential.

The game is not the best, but a very solid and enjoyable JRPG in my opinion. I would definitely recommend trying it out.
I also have to mention that Fairy Fencer F has a really good optimization. It runs on my pre-historic dualcore like a charm.

reviewText:
Opening this game after a few months and already feeling the nostalgia.

I bought this game the moment it came out. I don't regret it cause was very easy and a pleasure to play for a noob such as me. Really, you could be the worst player in the world who lost to Punchbag Bob, but you can't go wrong in Fairy Fencer F. I realised I may as well have been playing some kind of a nuzlocke because none of my party ever got KOd.

I HATE farming, but in this game it wasn't so bad. Characters get 'Weapon Points' for each battle you win, these WP are used to unlock attacks/skills and you can spend them to unlock whatever you want in ANY order. It's quite liberating and as killing enemies wasnt too hard either, unlocking all those skills felt achievable once I saw how much WP I was getting. Next...Next...Neext....Neeeext!!" I didn't get it until I started farming like this haha.

I enjoyed playing through the story. I enjoyed the farming. I want to play more games like this..."

reviewText:
Very good game. Overall good port from console, even if you want to play with mouse/keyboard (needs a little remapping, but not that much).

Story-wise, this game is a typical J-RPG : the main part of the narration are the relations between the main characters, which have various personnalities. The story/universe is original enough to keep us interested, but not used to its full potential. Instead, it's used to bring more dialogs and character-development. Like most J-RPG. You like it or you don't, it's just a matter of taste. But if you like J-RPG, you'll probably like it.
Like usual : you play western RPG for the world, eastern RPG for the characters.

Now the graphics : pretty good. Full 3D anime-style with VN-like dialogs. The FPS are steady everywhere, the loadings are fast. You never really wait while playing this game.

Gameplay-wise, it's a mix between action-RPG and turn-based RPG. Mostly turn-based. But it's complex enough to allow strategy during the battles. Not that much as a full T-RPG. If you like T-RPG, but don't want to think to much or like the visuals of action-RPG, then this battle system is for you.
However, battles can become a bit boring when you travel across a dungeon filled with weak enemies. But since we can avoid most battles, it's not that bad.

Balancing : I haven't reached the end-game yet, but I can already see it coming. The main character is just a beast. Unlock the right skill (I don't remember which, but it's fairly fast to unlock), and spam it against medium-strong enemies. Money is not a problem after like 2-3 hours, so you can buy lots of TP potions and spam your skills. So, the strategy is : buff your main character, use him to focus on the DPS (don't waste damage on near-dead enemies unless you really need to lower their number), and finish the crumbs with the other characters. The support character can deal some damage, but not enough to really match the dps of the main character. I find this kinda sad : all other strategies make the battles a lot longer, and thus bring boringness.

Last words : worth buying, worth playng, if you like J-RPG. You probably won't play it for 10 hours straight (it's not the kind of game that makes forget the flow of time), but you'll have no problem playing it like 2-3 hours a day everyday until you finish the game once or twice, since it's very enjoyable.

Story and Gameplay
Solid story with good twists and turns
Gameplay style is a bit like the Hyperdemension Neptunia games
Overall a good story with multiple heartwarming endings
Summary and My Personal Opinion
This game has an amazing story with loveable characters. The anime artstyle is something I like and this game preformed it well. In short, if you like a game with a JRPG style game with a nice combat system and an amazing story, I highly recommend this game.   8.7/10  Migs Approved
