reviewText:
Well after completing the game for the 1stime <Just started ng+> I think i can express my opinion now. So the game itself is a fantastic JRPG it's more then i ever expected to be honest i didnt have such high hopes for it but after 15 minutes with this game i got consumed by it and couldn't stop to play :D. You play the game as Fang which is in my opinion the most funniest and trollish main hero i ever saw :D And with that lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and of course your other friends around you struggle around the world to collect the Furies and revive the Goddess.

Good ones:
+Epic and funny story
+Epic combat system
+Kawaii Usagi San <Later in the game>

Bad ones:
-Not so many spells or special attacks as of Agarest for Example
-No wonderfull special team combos or hidden special attacks containing 3-4 party members
-Not so great talent and stat system

And if you dont want to break your game experience dont spend your money on Additional Fairy Pack or even the Weapon Change Accessory Set and Armor Pack. On the description of Weapon Change Set it's said that's only cosmetic  but when you equip it it boosts your ATKP and MTKP tremendously. Same goes fo the Fairy Pack which gives you few ridicilously overpowered Faries but they cant be used for Godly Revival. Their stat growth and passive talents are game breaking.

After all i reaaaly recommend this game for JRPG Beginners and Pro's alike ^^

reviewText:
Okay I'm going to keep this short and sweet folks. Pretty much if you have played Re;Birth 1 with all of the DLC you would know something about this.... somewhat. Aside from that there will be similarities with most of the dungeons and monsters as well too if you've played a NepNep game as well.

In any case it is worth getting since this has a bit more of a serious storyline to it than what NepNep has at times. Also, since this is an Iffy game expect a Grindfest for certain things, such as the Pub Quests, and sometimes leveling to do other things like the DLC dungeons.

Although there is also things that can be easily missable if you don't check everything before progessing into a storyline dungeon. Most of the things that can be missed is Lola's Side Quests, and thankfully there's a guide for that along with getting another secret character too.

So if you're thinking this is just :nepnep: reskined, you're only half right. Since they do have male Fencers involved in this..... and Pippin too, since I have no idea what that cat creature really is, just like the rest of the members in Fang's Party too.

In any case if you're on the fence for this game, I would suggest buying it when it goes on sale of course. :Eryn:

reviewText:
It reminds me of Final Fantasy: Crystal Chronicles from the Gamecube. Not quite the same, but similar playstyle with similar battle mechanics and loot drops. I would highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys turn based JRPGs. If you like Final Fantasy games, I would also suggest this to you.

+Good Humor
+Fun Combat System
+Fairly customizable (In terms of powers/items)
+Good loot system
+Fairly Challenging Gameplay
+Somewhat interesting story
+/- Decent graphics albeit a bit outdated
-Repetitive

Overall I would give this game a 7.5/10

It's definitely one of the better JRPGs on steam as of 2015, but it won't blow you away. The first 10 hours or so are awesome and going further it tends to be more of the same. That's not a bad thing, but if you get bored easily you may want to look elsewhere. For $15 this game is definitely worth it, but if you were going to pay $30 I'd wait for it to go on sale.

reviewText: Ethel is cute! CUTE!

Just finished this game recently, all i need to do now :

GRINDING for 100 million GOLD that is .. Easy achievement, just need some hardwork.

Now let me review things up.

PROS :
1. Battles are very similiar to your typical Idea Factory game such as Neptunia, which is easy for me to understand.

2. The WP Systems are unique since you don't need to bother ur equipment such as changing it (Armor and acc''re exceptional). You get to choose how the character would be, like if you improve their P-ATK, they'll be hitting as hard as they could and vice versa with the other attributes.

3. Some of you might not know about this, but I found this interesting recently. If you change the voice from English to Japanese, you get to hear your fairy's voice act whenever u open the Fairies tab, since it didn't worked that way on English VA.

4. Stories are good. Each protagonist have their own problem and are pretty interesting to talk with.
Game itself is fun, since it pretty much have a fun dialogues.

CONS :
1. It's getting pretty easy on 2/3rd playthrough, since everything are much easier without handicap. (Handicap : Like add monster lvl to increased its HP, DMG, DEF, exp and gold or sth).

2. The DLCs (except the costumes) are ruining the fun of this game. Told you, this game is ALREADY easy as it is without DLC, so don't bother to buy the Ultimate Weapon pack and others, unless you don't want to waste your time for 50 hours ++ grinding for 100% Steam Achievements. (44hrs gameplay and 86% achievement)

3. Maps are pretty much the same, developer only change your spawn point, which is lame IMO, LMAO. But it was something to be expected since this is an IDEA FACTORY game (I've played many of IF's games on console)

My conclusion :
8.5/10
If you like Anime style JRPG, with a rich story you should consider on buying this.
Don't buy this game if you don't care about the story, cause that's pretty much what makes the game INTERESTING in my opinion.

I'll start by reaffirming what others have said, if you enjoyed Neptunia then you will enjoy this game. I'm almost at the end so I may change some things upon completion but I'll just note how I feel so far.

Story: It's nothing to write home about, the plot twists and the like are really obvious. That being said, just like in Neptunia it is really the characters that make the story enjoyable. The humor is good, and unlike some Rebirth 2, it doesn't really use whole lot of memes. The character interactions are fun and Tsunako is responsible for their designs which is always great in my opinion.

Gameplay: Again, see Neptunia. There can be a lot of grind depending on what you're trying to do but if you just play through you should have no trouble. In fact, the only time I felt there was a difficulty spike was on certain side missions when attempting to get extra furies. You have your level ups, increasing the strength of each character but beyond that there is the Weapon Points system, which allows you to choose extra stat bonuses as well as customize progression through choices in combo moves, as well as extending both combos and weapon range. The fury system serves the duel purpose of prividing both character boosts through stat upgrades as well as allowing you to change each area in subtle but noticable ways. You could increase both the weapons points gained while at the same time doubling the damage BOTH you and your enemies put out. Depending on how you use them, you can speed up some of the grind in game.

Controls: I mainly played with an Xbox 360 controller. Despite this the controls were very repsonsive. I only add this because I recently went through the PS3 version of Neptunia Victory and found the controls to be somehat lagging in comparison. I breifly used KB+M to get a feel in that regard, and for the short time I used them if felt just as good.

Music: Enjoyable, like most jrpg's if you like em the music is usually good, and Compile Heart always does well in that regard.

If you typically enjoy a lot of the jrpg's that have been coming out lately, you'll no doubt find this a charming and enjoyable game. I've still yet to beat it so I can't say much for replay value, but judging from what I've played it doesn't seem like there could be much, at least until more of the DLC is released. It's worth the time and for those still on the fence, if you catch it on sale like I did, it is more than worth the money. Between the characters, story, and gameplay, you'll find a very comfy rpg.

Awesome game, i was engrossed in the whole story very quickly.

So Fairy Fencer F is a game where you are on a journey to collect fairies from furies, i will get to those in a second. So the game starts off with introducing the main character, Fang, who is one of the laziest protagonists ive ever seen, his first priority in any situation is food, and next is sleep. Having heard that pulling a fury out of teh ground will let him make any wish, and with a wish for food, he pulls the fury out and in turn becomes a Fencer, who wield a fury, and the fairy Eryn is introduced. She is really funny, and is the stragiht man to his antics, like food and sleep. They go on a journey and you meet another fencer in the first dungeon, but i wont go into detail as the story is one to experience for oneself. Just one quick word, ive only played a small amount of the story but its so gripping i cant stop, and have already played near 5 hours in the story mode (The ingame menu will tell you the total play time and this sessions play time)

The tutorial level comes quite quickly in this game and i for one love the combat system. Its turn based but each turn a character can move around a field in the map that has their starteing position as teh center of teh field.
When your characters turn is in play, they can choose a variety of options, those being attack, skills/magic, items, wait and fairize. Ill get to attack a bit later.
The skills/magic menu when opened has two submenus for skills and magic, skills being physical attacks. Many different magics and skills have different radii and fields where you need to line up the attacking area, which is in red, with the enemies you want to fight.
Huh? Whats Fairize you ask? Its sounds wierd but its where a fencer resonates with their fairy and thus their attack increases and special fairize skills are unlocked, oh and you get an anime-esque transformation sequence. And then theres also wait, Increases attack in teh next turn and makes you guard. A queue of who goes next is displayed on teh left side of teh screen.
Now we'll get to attack. which when pressed can start a combo, this cant be done at the start, but as you go thorugh the game youll learn how to execute long combos.

As you go through the game collecting furies, they will have fairies which you can equip to your characters, which increase stuff like strength of sword/glaive/knuckle/etc attack or increase attack of one element of magic, you know earth air fire water. There is a way to make fairies stronger, but its part of teh story and i dont want to spoil anything.

All thats left to talk about is options, in which you can increase bgm voice and sound volumes seperatley and there a japanese to english voice switch, which is english default, which is a nice addition that i like seeing in these sorts of games.

I highly recommend this to beginners of teh jrpg genre, veterans of rpgs in general, and anyone who wants a nice singleplayer campaign rpg expereince.

The story is great and you will fall in love with the characters. The combat is somewhat the same as hyperdimention neptunia but now features a skill page that you can upgrade. Great game, pick it up when you can for many hours of gameplay and multiple play throughs.

Not the most in-depth jrpg on steam or anything, but it's worth checking it out.

The game is very repetitive(I know, it's a rpg, but that one's even more repetitive than the personas). You clear a level, go back to town, chat, clear a level go back to town and chat, all the way through the end.

The game is very easy and my god please play with the japanese voices, english ones will make you cringe every time you battle.

What I really liked with this game is how fast the battles can be, since you can skip every single animations. In fact you can also skip every scenes. I made one playthrough(newgame+) and skipped most battles and every scenes and it took me 45 minutes to make it, lol.

The game has some really good ideas done right, but it just gets boring very fast, even though I personally enjoyed it. The battles lack some strategy and some better weakness/resist system, as well as the character developpement is meh; once you're mid-late game it kinda halts there. Music is all right and the level design is a joke.

Late game; the characters are pretty much identical since they nearly got all the same stats, the only difference is the main character having some slight extras, and a few different spells here and there between the characters.

Fairy Fencer F also has plenty of side-quests and stuff, but it's really boring and pretty much identical to what you do in the storyline.

When I first saw the battle system i thought: Wow it's like Grandia/chrono trigger! But it easily fell appart once you fully understand it. It's still decent though. But it lacks strategy.

For my experience, I'd rate it an 8 since jrpgs are my favorite genre of games, but I EASILY understand the metacritic score of 66. The game feels empty and unpolished.

Also crashed on a few occasions.

If I were you, I wouldn't pay more than 10$ for it.

The tons of moves to learn and customizatons to acquire offset the somewhat limited-feeling overworld map. It honestly feels like I'm playing a anime, which I imagine was the goal. Highly recommended.

It might be unfair to say that this game existed just because the devs wanted to experiment new ways to improve the franchise's gameplay experience...

At least, that's what I thought during the first hours of the game. However, as time passed, I realized something....

Of course, core gameplay has been improved a lot. Combat is fast and snappy, and many other things...

And while the characters might not be as memorable as Neps, the story is actually deep this time around. There are evidences of character development, and the final scenes towards the end is actually quite touching. (Although I still have to say that it's quite cliché.)

Some of the franchise's core problems still remain though. For instance, excessive recycling of assets. Story inconsistencies in some cutscenes when incorporated with optional content, bad voice recording and mixing in some parts, and so on.

Nevertheless, it's still a decent game with tons of rooms for improvement (FFF:ADF?). Overall worth buying.

I go to the first area, some foresty place, which gives me some free roam, which is awesome, except that after the first battle, the graphics will freeze. The game gives me two images it shifts between, imagine a gif with only two frames. Annoying, eh? That's what I get. However, the game is still playing, and I have even won battles in this utterly confusing state! I mean, I think I won them. I haven't been able to find a fix and would most certainly be thrilled if someone gave me a fix, but for now I am utterly perplexed why this keeps happening in almost the same spot. It is aggravating and I wish to play more of the game, but cannot. SO if this game works for you, it is most certainly worth it! If it doesn't work for you, well, junt a fix better than I? If you have found a fix, I would be glad to listen.

>> AWESOME ORIGINAL SOUNDTRACKS. Even if you don't understand Japanese, the soundtracks will still hit you right in da feels. :v

I give 8.5 out of 10 for this game. This studio never fails me. Let's keep it that way, devs!

Alright. Review time. After quite a few hours with this game, I can safely go into detail about whether you should buy it or not, keeping it spoiler free.

If you are TL:DR then here's the nutshell version: I love it.

STORY: Again not going to spoil anything in the story and rather experience it yourself. However, in terms of how good it is...It can be slow to repetitive at times, and i think I skipped a scene at one point because I felt it was irrelevant. The story itself is okay with quite a few twists to keep things refreshing. Though I feel that the story may be the weakest element in the game, AGAIN not that it's bad, it's enjoyable, but it ain't exactly perfect. If it's worth something, I did tear up a bit at times from certain heavy moments. SADLY: You don't get to make any real choices, it's rather straight forward with only three endings. One you get from ignoring all subevents involving your party. And two for...just google it.

Characters: Most if not all of them are brimming with personality and are unique in their own way, including the Fairies in which our main characters possess. The protagonist thankfully is not the cliche brave and goody-to-shoes hero, rather far from it as you will see if you start the game. Each character is lovable and I remember their names well, and I'm bad at remembering names, so that's quite the accomplishment.

Gameplay: Turn based as one might expect. Nothing much to say. You can use basic attacks, magic, or special animated skills to attack your opponents. You may also customize combos in which to attack your enemies with. Each character also has a special ability with special effects for each individual. There are other elements as well which are quite refreshing, but I don't feel like going into detail since it would be explained in the game later.

Soundtrack: Fairly nice, especially when you use you VERY VERY powerful ability or 'FAIRIZE' as well. Though it can get a bit bland, but overall there are some tracks that stick out.

Voice Acting: FOCUS FOCUS FOCUS FOCUS!!! This is important! In my opinion i highly recommend you play this game with the japanese voice over in the options tab. The english dub is...there for those who really hate japanese, but I don't...find them believable like I do with the japanese Dub. The characters feel more alive without the english voice over, and the experience with the game fell a bit when I tried the english version for a while. Japanese is my recommended voice over.

Overall rating: I would at least give this game a 8/10. Still places to improve on, but I've played a solid 24 hours with it, and even if you beat the game, you can restart the story without losing all your progress and restarting. There is replay value depending how you do on the first run.

WARNING: I do not think there is an autosave for this game so before you leave and murderize your computer when you come back, always save. ALWAYS. I didn't lose any progress because i was paranoid as hell since the game leaves save points to help you do it manually. But you can also do it on the world map.

Hope this was helpful.

I could write a long review, but I'll try to keep this kind of short. Besides, I'm biased.

I will try to keep this spoiler-free. Put simply, Fairy Fencer F might not be for everyone, but if you like turn-based JRPGs, lots of customization, or VN-styled cutscenes, it's perfect. Plus there are waifus. And husbandos, if you like that.

Pros:
+ Runs very smoothly, even on my toaster computer (you can change resolutions too)
+ Tons of customization with World Shaping/Furies and the WP system
+ Cute art, cool designs, and likable characters, with character development!
+ Not your typical battle system - action yet turn-based, tension gauge which you use to 'Fairize' aka power up
+ Cool skills, and you can also skip them and make battles go much faster by holding down the Next button
+ Fully voiced in Japanese! Even the fairies are voiced!!
+ Multiple endings and subevents in a kinetic visual novel style; multiple playthroughs available/needed
+ Harley and Ethel

YMMV
* Very easy without any way to change the difficulty
* Difficulty also doesn't change on next playthrough, though makes the playthrough much faster
* Synthesizing/alchemy and quest system, but don't have any real impact or incentives
* Some of the OST is memorable, but others are just typical RPG fare (I like the second Fairize song best)
* Dungeons and 3D look alright, but are reused and are fairly short
* Plot twist is only somewhat predictable, but a little frustrating

Cons:
- Pretty bland setup with some stereotypes and a cliche JRPG backstory (two deities fought, good vs. evil, wish-granting)
- Characters might seem annoying at first (Fang was awful at the beginning, but even he matures by the end)
- No Harley or Ethel route
- Godly Revival has no effect on actual story (you'll see what I mean)

Basically, get it because Tiara is best girl.

It's a great rpg game that follows most of the old classic rpg elements.
level grinding: check
loot farming: double check unforunately (you'll know why)
GREAT and LOVEABLE CHARACTERS: YES! (except for that one guy, spoilers)

If you liked Neptunia, this is for you.\nA different universe makes a huge difference and I simply adore this game because of it (Although I miss Nep). If you never played a Idea Factory or Compile Heart game and are looking for both fun gameplay and hilarious characters then look no farther then Fairy Fencer F.

I thoroughly enjoyed Fairy Fencer F as is apparent by my play time. The game play is very similar to Hyper-dimension Neptunia and take the role of a third person turn based RPG. The level grinding in the game never got to tedious and each battle did require some strategy and the characters equipment and move customisation took quite a lot of thinking, you could also put certain effects on the dungeons which put even more thought into what to do. The story is overall very engaging a throws some unexpected curve balls that even I, an avid anime fan and RPG player didn't see coming, which should be commended. The humour in Fairy Fencer F should also be praised, it had me laughing quite a few times. The characters are one of the best parts of the game, the main character, Fang's character development was really incredible as he retains his attitude but at the same time turns into an empathetic character who genuinely cares about his friends. The other characters such as Tiara and Eryn get little to no character development (excluding Ethel, best girl) but are still funny, admirable and relatable, you really do come to care about these characters. The music was also overall good though some tracks did start to lose some appeal after a while they still remained decent to listen to. There is also a fair amount of stuff to do after you finish the game and is impossible to do everything in one play through. Okay I've talked this game up enough time to delve into it's flaws.

First of all the difficulty, in my first play through I completed the game in about 32 hours during that time I died twice. For clarification one of those times was because I wasn't paying attention to the game and did one battle too many while EXP grinding. As long as you aren't a complete idiot and pay attention this games difficulty isn't that high and overall isn't the most challenging though I'm an RPG veteran. Secondly, there was a point where they say you have to pull all the swords out of goddess to unseal them and then they completely forget about it and it has no impact on the ending. Thirdly, the ridiculous hidden characters/fairies, as an RPG I understand secret characters are going to be difficult to unlock but Lola's requirements are really unforgiving as you need to complete all of her side quests, which are really easy to miss. For the two S-rank fairies I have no issue but one particular A-rank fairy, Dohn, is completely asinine much worse than Lola. To unlock him you need to do a  pub request that only appears when you haven't completed a certain dungeon and you have to complete it immediately and you get it after you complete the dungeon. Now you might think that's not so bad but allow me to provide some context, you get given no signs that you get this fairy after completing this request, the quest is only available for a short while when you haven't completed a dungeon so you are viable to miss it. Adding onto the chance of missing it is the fact that pub requests barely offer any good rewards for completing them and most of the time you won't have requests high up on your priorities. All of this culminates in a fairy that even harder to get than the S-ranks.

I think that this game is for casual gamers who haven't got all the time in the world but can spare a couple hours a week to play this game. It's funny, engaging and entertaining.
Overall, a good game.
Fairy Fencer F , Is the MOST Dramatic & Fun game ever!

reviewText: A game which at its core plays very similarly to the Neptunia series, with a few differences such as how combos are set up and some skills are unlocked. The story is pretty light hearted with some darker bits in at part, so it's not just a circus show the whole time or anything like that, playing out more kind of like a comedic anime with serious undertones here and there. Characters and the music are great, though there are a couple of missable optional party characters, so be careful about those. Good luck on that 100 Million G achievment though.

Fariy Fencer F i would say is a great game with a great story and good gameplay in some aspects.

The gameplay is like the hyperdimension games where you have your ususal attacks and combos (to get combos you need to level up your weapon by weapon boosting) and you have your special attacks in this case skills and magic attacks along with an attack only avalible in the farize form. Farize form could be related to the hdd in neptunia but its not like that you need to fill the tension bar to a certian point and then you can select the farize form what comes along with some good music where everything is buffed up but you can be sent out of this form due to the tension bar what needs to be kept a look at when using this form. Lastly theres special moves what only that character can use this can range from a buff in strength (Fangs Serious face gives a buff in strength but causes every attack to cost SP) these moves are balanced in certian ways but can be usefull where you can scan the enemy to see their stats so you can plan what attack to use next but these do take up a turn so be sure to keep the character using the move safe and not low on health.

The music in this game is amazing with every new place having its own track along with certian boss fights getting their own music and with the farize theme (theres 2 farize themes with the second being the more better one). I would say that the music is worth the listen to.

The story is what makes the game that good (along with the gameplay of course) and the story does have its moments where the tone changes and it changes alot in this game. I wont say nothing really relating to the main plot itself due to spoilers and you need to experience the story at first hand to have some really good reactions.

I would recommend this game to fans of rpgs and jrpgs and probably to the fans of the hyperdimension series. I would also recommend this to really anyone looking to start playing jrpgs and rpgs this would be a good one to start at.

There is some problems mainly going towards using an xbox one controller but that can be fixed easily with downloading the old drivers again to fix it and aside from that there really is not that many problems with the game itself.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F is quite relaxing when you have the DLC with it.
But I think the DLC isn't a bother even if its made easier to play, what matters to me was the storyline. This JRPG was especially better to me than the Neptunia series because it's amazing how each character has their own unique background already.

Art : I actually been in love with the artist for a while, but the models of the weapons actually brings my attention more because damn, it looks cool.

Story : Overall the story was good, but the endings weren't as exciting to be honest.

Characters : Characters are the ones that made me feel like the game was special. With their own characteristics, and their fairy makes them exciting.

Gameplay System : What disturbs me the most on the battle system was the same looking attack animation each time (I only did same combos because of the damage output). Nonetheless, the skills, magics etc were actually quite cool to use, but I also like the idea of the fury effect. It somehow made it easier to farm WP + Levels.

Bonus : Sequel? I seen the trailer but seriously, 6 people in one battle party? Would be nice to display more but I am more concerned to watch every single one of them. But it makes me wonder how the story would go.

reviewText:
Fun game, but there is no difficulty slider and eventually you end up just playing it for the story and not for the gameplay.

Exploring dungeons is pointless, there's nothing to look at (graphics are console/outdated), nothing to explore too. You're better off going in a straight line to the objective in every dungeon instead of looking for loot/monsters to kill. Side quests are practically worthless, rewards are ok but when you literally stomp every enemy your level (and then some) you don't really need to be careful when playing. For perspective, I had to play against enemies 2x my level to even get a sort of challenge, since I couldn't roflstomp enemy mobs then. So don't buy it for the gameplay.

Story wise though it was fun. Funny to play through, has funny little bits of trivia that you can pick up while you're in town by other civilians, though those interactions are just going to a menu (kinda) and selecting characters to talk to.
Ignoring the side stories, the main storyline is quite enjoyable. Only problem" would be that it's not particularly deep in terms of character development

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F is an interesting game, it somewhat appears in the shadow of the Hyperdimension series and with the polish that those games had you should have high expectations for this one.

In the end those expectations are met. It certainly is fun and hilarious, you really cant go wrong with it, there is a pretty nice bang for buck with this title.

Storyline: At first its pretty linear and well it drags you along with what seems like a cookie cutter story. Well things change and things happen which arent expected. The various endings are a bit lack luster though, they are bitter sweet but leave you wanting more. Though im not sure if this is getting a sequel, not even sure how they could do a sequel with the storyline this has. Its a lot more serious then hyperdimension but its still full of various jokes.

Combat: The combat is very similar to that of hyperdimension's, by that i mean its got nice effects, nice moves, variation etc etc. Unless hyperdimension you have to earn the combats and the amount of attacks you can do, personally i think its a bit of a pain, it can become a grind fest. You control three charecters in this game.

The port: The port is good, no crashes at all, audio lag for a few seconds if you tab out but that fixes itself very quickly. Textures are serviceable, they could be higher res but i cant complain, they are good enough. The game runs at a solid 60fps. It uses the windows resolution system which means you can go nuts with the resolution options, you want 4k thats fine, want 8k yeah it works(suprisingly well with my 680 20fps at 8k isnt bad).

Overall: If you like anime, rpgs, funny storys, bang for buck, multiple endings, hack n slash etc then this is a really nice game to buy.

Side note this game is optimized for a controller which honestly you guys need, many games work a lot better with controllers and this is one of them. it would be nice for it to be optimized for mouse and keyboard, id say that is currently the biggest issue.

reviewText:
So first things first, if you like the gameplay of Neptunia Re;Birth 1 and 2, you're probably going to like it here, 'cause it's pretty much the same. I have no problem with that because frankly I adore this battle system. Rather than just picking an enemy (or several enemies) like a typical JRPG, you move around a limited area on your turn and pick enemies then, sometimes with a box or something for which enemies you're going to hit. It adds a little extra element to it, in my opinion. Unlike Neptunia, basic attacks use a selection rather than an aiming box, so you can only attack one enemy at a time.

Personally I quite liked the story aswell, and as expected from Compile Heart (or at least, coming from Neptunia) I especially liked the characters. Except the ones I wasn't meant to like. There are only very few characters I don't find myself caring about, and they were either generic NPCs or showed up for only a short time. I do like how each o the fairies you collect has their own personlity in the menu, though.

In terms of being a port, it seems to be rather good. It's not once ran slowly for me, and in fact the framerate appears to be an improvement from the 30 that the PS3 original apparently had. I've only found one minor glitch so no problems there either. I don't know how well Keyboard and Mouse control, but it seems to have keyboard icons for menus which is a step up from Neptunia also.

All in all, I liked it. Whether you're going to like it, well, that's up to your opinon, but if you can't find anything about it you mind then I say give it a shot.

reviewText:
While this game suffers from a good amount of flaws (see below for details), it still manages to be an enjoyable experience.
I'll be speaking numbers and mechanics so you get to know exactly what to expect from this product, and whether it's for you or not.
If you've played other games from this developer (like the Neptunia series), you can expect lots of similar aspects.



The good points :
- Fairy Fencer F takes about 25 hours to complete, and about 60 hours to get all achievements (I'm nearly there, so it's an estimate). This is a decent amount of time for an RPG, and at this price point, it's quite reasonable.

- While the story is kind of a classic (hero must defeat an evil god), the narrative makes it enjoyable. A few plot twists here and there, with some of them being predictable, and some others not (which is the good part). The main protagonist doesn't have your typical hero" personnality
date: which is refreshing. Interactions between characters are good enough
recommended: and you can get attached to some of them. This is a good sign

reviewText: So I'm four hours in and I found Fairy Fencer F rather enjoyable. Just a warning though, if you get ambushed next to certain walls while jumping it is possible that once the battle is over you'll be stuck between the ceiling/pipe and the floor. Make sure to save often and in multiple spots and everything will be fine. It's very customizable and has great pacing.

reviewText: Bought this game while its on discount, decided to try it out. Enter the game and it seems more like visual novel with anime theme. Thought to myself, did I bought the wrong game @.@ After playing for a couple of minutes, and yes, the conversation is like visual novel style, but gameplay consist of dungeon. Your job in the game is to collect fairies and boost your stats. How you grow, depends on how you build your character. Highly recommend this game! You won't regret it if you don't hate grinding.

reviewText:
Essentially an inferior version of Hyperdimension Neptunia with different skins.
Battles provide almost 0 challenge
Story full of plot holes that don't get filled in a satisfactory way
Multiple game mechanics and stats that are useless

Fun characters and character interactions
Absolutely fantastic English dub

Play this game for the VN style cutscenes or to get your Nep Nep fix from this if you're out of Neptunia games to play otherwise not worth it

weeaboosonly/10

reviewText:
I don't do many of these, and I don't really intend to do many more, mostly because I usually don't care enough for the games to do a review about them.
As you can see, i still haven't played this game for that long but I think i can already write something about it.
This is a fun game. It's not amazing, it's not the best thing ever, it's simply what a game should be, fun and entretaining. It doesn't try to go beyond and break any new barriers, but it also isn't lazy or badly done.

The story is not really that special, but it keeps you engaged enough to keep on wanting to know what's going to happen. Not going to give any details because that would take forever.


The characters are stereotypes that anyone is used to see in any anime. Though the main character is by far the most entretaining character because he really does not seem to care for the main quest, not even for the other characters... to a certain extent. But his interaction with Eryn, and the rest of the group do make them more interesting then what they are in their roots.


The gameplay is redundant. It's always the same thing over and over again. Usualy this is a problem, except for the fact that the gameplay is rather fun, so it doesn't really matter. The special attacks feature some nice animations and the transformations get you really pumped expecially when you are fighting a boss.

The music complements the game nicely and the world in itself is rather charming.

Overall this is a really nice game that will make you want to play it for hours and hours. There is alot of stuff to do like side quests and other fairies to find, skills to upgrade, etc, so you will always have something to do.

If i had to rate, i would give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
If you like JRPGs and liked Hyperdimension Neptunia then this is a must.

The MC is so damn good he's funny and to the point but is very single minded, just thinking about some of the dialog brings a smile.

There are more features and RPG elemets then the Neptunia games and this adds a nice level of depth once you work out what you're doing which wont take long. The game seems more blanced then the Neptunia games I've had to use a lot more healing items and revive dead party memebers ect.

Also you have to power up you gauge to go into Fryrice"mode and healing makes the gaguge go down so you have to manage you healing and attacking cycles better then you did in HDN were you just rolfstomped everything in Goddess mode.

Will add more when I've played more but so far this has been worth every penny I paid for it."

reviewText:
This reveiew is based on one playthrough of the game.  Considering the achievements (of which many are rediculous), the game is expected to be played through multiple times (NG+).

FYI : TLDR at the bottom.

Storyline - 8/10 - Actually has a clearly explained plot line.  Some plot twists and variation of character. Very comedic.

Character Development - 7/10 - The intereactions b/t characters is fun, energetic, and sometimes realistic.  Very few of the character's personalities evolve.

Gaemplay - 6.5/10 - The bar for the difficulty lvl is set way to low.  It's not in the least bit hard.  I expected at least some challenge.  I'm not counting the lvl req'd DLC dungeons(which aren't plot related and aren't req'd to be completed or even played at all), that's a cop-out.

At least fairies could be used to modify the stats of any given dungeon.  So if you just wanted things to be hard, you could make it so no spells/ablilties can be used, chars take dbl dmg, have reduced resistances, can't cure debuffs, etc.  On the flipside, +% exp/gold/WP/stats/droprate.  Most faires gave both a (+) & a (-).  Still didn't improve overall game difficulty.

Battles are easy to learn, manage, and fun to watch. Quickly becomes repetitive.

Equipment was too easy to come by to bother making it with mats. Level growth was automatic boosts to all stats, and the only variation is via equipped Fairy and Weapon Points (WP).  Don't get me started on the player specific abilities, that is a sordid story rife with complaints.

On the plus side WP had a good deal of variation, but alot of the magic/weapon attacks seemed either useless or overtly interchangeable with 2-3 others.  Why would I want to use magic to cure a debuff if there is an item for it?   Nothing in the game denies the use of items.  Granted AoE dispell of all debuffs was nice, but characters were only ever afflicted with one at any given time.  Not mentioning most were temporary or lacked any sort impact on the battle.

It was fun to make a bunch of items I'd never need or use, though. (Max Elixirs, the AoE HP pots, etc)

Some people complain about the AoE targeting sensitivity being too high, but these people are just lazy. This is easily remedied by rotating the camera.

Game Stability and Hardware Req'd - 9/10 -  Game has low hardware requirements but remains nice to look at.  Art style and quality gel together well.  Objects in the world look like they belong and doesn't have any obvious/jarring visual errors.

Loses a point for poor dungeon initialization programming.  Major FPS drops everytime a new dungeon is loaded, due to all the mobs being spawned simultaneously.  Major programming bug that should have been fixed prior to port.

Voice Acting and Music - 9/10 - To my surprise, the english voice acting was superb.  I'll probably play through the game again with the original voices to see how it compares, but not anytime soon.

Music was enjoyable for the first 10hrs or so. By then you've heard almost 80% of the music you'll hear all game and they're just on repeat.  Was nice that one of the battle specific songs was swapped out halfway through.  It was seriously grinding on my nerves, by then.

TLDR

Overall, I enjoyed the game.  The characters were entertaing to watch and the plot held together.   NOT worth $30.  I'd consider it to be worth $20.

I still recommend it for the story and characters.  It was fun to play through and I will prolly play NG+ one time through just to see what it's like and what changes.

Note:  Despite seeing alot of reviews referencing the Neptunia series, I've only played a few hours of Rebirth and hated it.  There are similarities in gameplay, but the story here isn't a bland piece of s*** built solely for comedic effect and wrought with plotholes.  I do give kudos to the Neptunia series for actually presenting me with at least some gameplay challenges, though.

reviewText: Compile’s plan with Fairy Fencer F was to try and prove that they’re more than an endless conveyor belt of Hyperdimension Neptunia releases, which they have tried to prove by slapping a new IP atop a modified Hyperdimension Neptunia engine. reviewText:
Since all the comments already addressed what's good about this game, there are a lot of missable things in this game.

Hidden Character #1 is unlocked by beating Apollonius while being level 40 the 2nd time

Hidden Character #2 is unlocked by doing all 16 of Lola's quest

The missable hidden fairy is unlocked by having a B quest rank and finishing the emergency B quest upon finishing Blast furnace (only achievable at NG+)

Otherwise, I managed to achieve level 100 at 45 hours of the game, which is due to its addicting combat system

Why would I want to use magic to cure a debuff if there is an item for it?   Nothing in the game denies the use of items.  Granted AoE dispell of all debuffs was nice, but characters were only ever afflicted with one at any given time.  Not mentioning most were temporary or lacked any sort impact on the battle.

It was fun to make a bunch of items I'd never need or use, though. (Max Elixirs, the AoE HP pots, etc)

Some people complain about the AoE targeting sensitivity being too high, but these people are just lazy. This is easily remedied by rotating the camera.

Game Stability and Hardware Req'd - 9/10 -  Game has low hardware requirements but remains nice to look at.  Art style and quality gel together well.  Objects in the world look like they belong and doesn't have any obvious/jarring visual errors.

Loses a point for poor dungeon initialization programming.  Major FPS drops everytime a new dungeon is loaded, due to all the mobs being spawned simultaneously.  Major programming bug that should have been fixed prior to port.

Voice Acting and Music - 9/10 - To my surprise, the english voice acting was superb.  I'll probably play through the game again with the original voices to see how it compares, but not anytime soon.

Music was enjoyable for the first 10hrs or so. By then you've heard almost 80% of the music you'll hear all game and they're just on repeat.  Was nice that one of the battle specific songs was swapped out halfway through.  It was seriously grinding on my nerves, by then.

TLDR

Overall, I enjoyed the game.  The characters were entertaing to watch and the plot held together.   NOT worth $30.  I'd consider it to be worth $20.

I still recommend it for the story and characters.  It was fun to play through and I will prolly play NG+ one time through just to see what it's like and what changes.

Note:  Despite seeing alot of reviews referencing the Neptunia series, I've only played a few hours of Rebirth and hated it.  There are similarities in gameplay, but the story here isn't a bland piece of s*** built solely for comedic effect and wrought with plotholes.  I do give kudos to the Neptunia series for actually presenting me with at least some gameplay challenges, though.

reviewText:
I don't do many of these, and I don't really intend to do many more, mostly because I usually don't care enough for the games to do a review about them.
As you can see, i still haven't played this game for that long but I think i can already write something about it.
This is a fun game. It's not amazing, it's not the best thing ever, it's simply what a game should be, fun and entretaining. It doesn't try to go beyond and break any new barriers, but it also isn't lazy or badly done.

The story is not really that special, but it keeps you engaged enough to keep on wanting to know what's going to happen. Not going to give any details because that would take forever.


The characters are stereotypes that anyone is used to see in any anime. Though the main character is by far the most entretaining character because he really does not seem to care for the main quest, not even for the other characters... to a certain extent. But his interaction with Eryn, and the rest of the group do make them more interesting then what they are in their roots.


The gameplay is redundant. It's always the same thing over and over again. Usualy this is a problem, except for the fact that the gameplay is rather fun, so it doesn't really matter. The special attacks feature some nice animations and the transformations get you really pumped expecially when you are fighting a boss.

The music complements the game nicely and the world in itself is rather charming.

Overall this is a really nice game that will make you want to play it for hours and hours. There is alot of stuff to do like side quests and other fairies to find, skills to upgrade, etc, so you will always have something to do.

If i had to rate, i would give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
Decent JRPG with a solid battle system and leveling customization. Overall cast of characters are well-rounded and entertaining, having a lot of funny interactions. The story's premise is interesting and engaging enough and gets you emotionally invested with the cast. Surprisingly the fanservice in this game is much more tame than other Compile Heart works, which I personally don't mind. On average you can get anywhere from 20-30 hours on your first playthrough.

Solid game that I recommend to fans of both anime and JRPGs. If you're a fan of Compile Heart's previous games, you'll like this game.

All the girls are perfect but Harley is best girl.

reviewText:
When I started to play with this game my first impression was along the lines of:
God These characters are annoying!
The main character Fang acted like a lazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who cares about nothing but food. The main heroine and the face of the game Tiara acted like a giant SOB. The other heroine and the partner of Fang Eryn always seemed to have a few bad words for him.
Though to be fair Eryn did have a reason to act the way she did. Just imagine you wait (for only God knows how much) for a lifetime partner to finally show up. And then when he finally arrives the only thing you get from him is verbal abuse, unwillingness and constant complaining about food. You wouldn’t be happy about it either would you?
And then I kept on playing and the magic happened. When the characters started to really interact with each other and solving the problems life gave to them they turned out to be really well thought out and lovable.
I would say the main strength of the game is it’s brilliant writing. The plot is the average the bad boys wants to resurrect the bad God the good boys wants to resurrect the good God but fortunately it’s written in an entertaining way. The characters are not only good but they keep on developing and they get rid of their initial annoying quirks. The story itself is not ground-breaking but has it’s nice touches and has a plot-twist around the middle I DID NOT SEE COMING!
For the actual gameplay:
If you played Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 or Re;Birth 2 then all I say it’s exactly the same.
You enter dungeons from the main map. Inside them you control your assigned leader in the map picking up treasures and avoiding or hitting enemies. The actual battle system is turn based so when you are hit by one of them a battle sequence is initiated where your party fights against the monsters. When the battle is won you get back to the dungeon.
Interesting take that you can’t change weapons since each character has to fight with the fairy he or she has a contract with. In exchange you have a weapon upgrade system where you can raise your characters stats, teach them new abilities and moves, skills and magic trough Weapon Point earned by battling. However thank to this system your usual equipment are close to useless and the mostly serve as fanservice. In the game you will gather fairies you cannot equip as weapons but they can grant buffs and add dungeon effects using a system called world shaping. With them you can make the game a little bit harder or easier depending on you.
I think the biggest flaw of this battle system is that you became overpowered very very quick. After that battles are a chore instead of a challenge and the game becomes rather boring. The other downside is the quest system which requires extreme levels of grinding.
There are 3 endings available but there is little difference between them. One for Tiara one for Eryn and a normal ending if you chose neither. Tiara’s ending takes priority so avoid scenes with her if you want Eryn’s. You should chose Eryn by the way.^^
The game offers a new game+ too. Many content is unavailable in your first playtrough raising the replay value of the game even harder. If you are interested in missable content then there is two playable characters who cannot be recruited unless certain conditions are met and a bunch of time limited sub-events.
All in all I recommend this game for everyone who loves jrpgs and doesn’t mind grinding.

reviewText:
Since all the comments already addressed what's good about this game, there are a lot of missable things in this game.

Hidden Character #1 is unlocked by beating Apollonius while being level 40 the 2nd time

Hidden Character #2 is unlocked by doing all 16 of Lola's quest

The missable hidden fairy is unlocked by having a B quest rank and finishing the emergency B quest upon finishing Blast furnace (only achievable at NG+)

Otherwise, I managed to achieve level 100 at 45 hours of the game, which is due to its addicting combat system

reviewText:
This was my very first time playing a JRPG and also the first review I've ever done, so I'll keep it simple.
I'm not a very good judge when it comes to games so I can't point out specifics like other reviewers can.

However, I can tell you that this is very enjoyable game.
Why? Because I spent, literally speaking, an entire morning and afternoon playing it non-stop, without the slightest thought of quitting.

The amount of variety about the things I could use in battles, combined with the story, captivated me completely.
I recommend this only to newcomers regarding JRPGs, because, due to my lack of experience, I have no right to recommend it to veterans.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F, a game I owned on my Playstation 3 (I didn't get very far though due to the frame rate drops on the PS3 that I couldn't bear with) is a JRPG I would have to say is definetly worth a purchase. Though where to start...

The game itself is filled with humor that will make you smile, the characters are loveable and I personally am loving watching the story unfold and the characters all coming closer together, one humorous anime filled step at a time haha.
The combat is what you would expect from a game VERY similar to the Hyperdimension Neptunia series (also worth looking into if you are not familar) so not much I can really say there. It's short, sweet, and very simple to learn. The English voice acting is done right, as what is expected from the developers of these wonderful games.

Overall if you are wondering if this is a product worth purchasing, then in all my hearts honesty, of my own opinion of course, yes it definetly is worth buying. As I have gotten farther on the PC port then I was on my PS3, I have come to realize how much I have missed out on when it comes to the overall enjoyment this game has to offer.
Now of course this game has it's faults (mainly which comes to combat for me) but they are for the most part what would you expect if you have played any other heavily anime styled JRPG. I also wanted throw out as an almost last note the game is very well optimized right out the get go like everyone else has been saying. Something that the developers of these games have been having issues with when it comes to their ports. Anywhos...

I'll quit typing here as I know due to the lack of reviews I actually write... I'm not very great at them. But I sure as heck tried my best! Haha anyways like I mentioned, in my heart this game is a gem. I almost want to say this was a very underappreciated game that never really did get the love it deserves. So please if you're interested do purchase this game, As I can promise you won't regret it;)


As always I hope everyone is doing well and living life the best they can! And I wish everyone the best! :) And of course thank you for reading!!!

(I hope my review did justice or atleast did okay for anyone who reads this by the way haha!)

reviewText:
In the end, it's a mediocre JRPG, but it's still pretty fun. I'd recommend picking it up at 50-75% off, as you'll have a good time.

The battle system is pretty fun, but it lacks strategy. Just buy lots of SP healing items, spam your most powerful attacks and you're good to go.
Don't forget to buy the new attacks on the Weapons Boost" tab. Only realized you could do that in the second half of the game.

The story is enjoyable
date:
with a cast of likable casts and fun interactions between them.
But the actual plot is kinda awful. It just keeps jumping between plot points and never develops any of them. Doesn't help that this game loves to introduce antagonists just to kill them right after.

The worst thing about this game is that

reviewText: Fairy Fencer F is a lazy game, with a weak plot, that can be pretty fun if you catch it on sale.  I'm a little caught on whether to upvote or downvote, the flaws are SO numerous with this game, but it is still pretty enjoyable.  I'll tell you now, the game is very much average in my book (50-55% or 70-75% depending on what you consider average").\n\nFirst I'll address my "lazy" comment: why is the game lazy?  First
date: the battle system is just a tweaked version of what you may very well have seen five or six times before in the company's "Neptunia" series.  If it ain't broke
recommended: I'm certainly not going to tell them to fix it
hoursPlayed: though
voteText: because they might make something decidedly less inobtrusive.  As it stands
helpfulPercent: the battle system is fairly enjoyable
votesHelpful: you're given some freedom in picking which Persona *cough* I mean
votesTotal: Fairy to use
votesFunny: which augments your stats and grants you certain bonuses and debuffs that might effect your adventure through a dungeon
commentsCount: like an exp bonus at the expense of having lower defense
column16: more money but harder enemies spawn
column17: etc.  As you earn experience
column18: you also earn secondary exp referred to as "WP
column19:
which you can apply to the stats of your choice (if by choice, you mean adding extra attacks in battle through leveling Combo!).  Battle play out very....slowly...as characters have played out attack animations and the game requires a lot of loot farming to finish missions, luckily, this is rendered much less annoying by the fast forward button they let you use to skip animations.  Of course, a fast forward button is a bandaid solution to the greater problem that battles take very little strategy and the whole gameplay rythm relies on a lot of menial drudgery.

Side quests are lazy too.  Most of the missions in the game are shoved into a quest board with scant flavor text that is only really worth reading for the location and enemy information that it might (emphasis *might*, the times when it doesn't give you useful information are always on the rarest, most difficult-to-find items) provide.

Dungeon design is also...you get it by now.  Mostly corridors, with minimal interactibles except for the odd enemy or treasure...floating cube thing that very thoroughly fails to blend in with ANY scenery you happen to find it in.  Locales you visit have no real significance.  Go here for that MacGuffin, then go here for the next one, etc etc.  You could have flipped the order of most of the dungeons in the game and it wouldn't have really changed anything.

The plot is weak for a few reasons: the world, the characters, and the pacing.  First, the world is very shallow.  You have one hub town, and it's just a bunch of menus (Neptunia players will not be surprised by this).  There are NPC talk events that come up regularly, but most of them are either useless random comments about really nothing, like a drunk passing by or something, or vaguely silly scenes where an NPC does something weird and your character reacts to it.  World building is pretty much non-existant, except to further drive home the heavy-handed and simplistic world the main plot already sets up.  Main plot establishes really quickly: evil corporation appears good, but is really doing bad stuff!  Side NPCs occasionally: we love the evil corporation so much because they throw money at us, etc.
Second, the characters.  The characters for the most part sit very comfortably in shallow archetypes that they don't venture out of very often.  Even with fairly frequent talk topics after major plot developments, you never really see how the group becomes the True Companions that are willing to die for the main character despite his less than stellar charisma and lazy attitude for most of the game.  It doesn't help that the game resets about half way through, resetting character development for everyone except the main character in the process, and further shortening the character arcs (if you can even call them that) of the party members.
Third is the game's issue with pacing.  The fact that the timeline resets mid-game reeks as an excuse to reuse the already minimal-effort dungeons.  Indeed, after that mid-game reset, the game introduces about a handful of new dungeons, that might as well be reskins of the existing ones anyway.  This move also resets character development for most of the cast, turning the focus on the main character as he tries to convince them he isn't crazy and really IS from an alternate timeline.  If their motivations for joining the party weren't ALREADY flimsy (pervy researcher girl wants to come along so she can perv on your party's female fairies), they become seriously flimsy after the reset (hey, this crazy guy claims he's from the future, might as well tag along and perv on his fairies while I watch this play out).

Positives and Negatives Breakdown:
+Great port: Borderless windowed option, runs smooth even at high resolutions and at max detail.  No crashes, no save issues, works competently on keyboard+mouse, but best on a controller.
+Fun, if mindless dungeon crawling: the gameplay is fine.  The story can't really stand on its own, and there's little narrative or lore motivation to doing sidequests, but if you enjoy the gameplay, it's an alright treadmill to get on for a few hours.
+Good art--CGs in story events and character side-events are well done, frequently putting characters in pervy situations if that's your thing.
+/- Music--there are a few standout tracks, but it's mostly very bland and forgettable.
-Weak story
--Weak pacing
-Weak Characters
-Weak world-building
-Recycled dungeons out the wazoo

reviewText:
I actually really like this game, it got the second Neptunia game out of my mouth.

In basic terms yes it is very similar but with good differences.

The combat system has changed the element of striking enemies into a selective area.
You won't get all your skills from just leveling it up but by unlocking them with these sort of perk" points used to buff damage
hoursPlayed: your Fairy form "transformation" and  giving you more combos
voteText: that's right you don't get your entire combo from the start.\n1st The transformation has a subtle change
helpfulPercent: whenever you get hit or hit an enemy out of form you have a bar representing tension that will rise
votesHelpful: after a certain amount filled up you nca fairize which does not cost anything and basically turns you into a badass
votesTotal: thing is it's not permenant
votesFunny: whenever you take a hit the bar falls hard
commentsCount:
so no more permanent powerup.
Each character has an actual move specified to them Fang the main character can buff his attack and skills for an extra energy cost to each attack and multiplier to the cost of skills.
Tiara can put up a barrier around herself to reflect a large portion of damage but is unable to attack.
Every character can transform
column16: you are all Fairy Fencers
column17: you can all Fairize.\nThe story still has comedy but at certain parts the story can and will take a turn for the dark
column18: people actual will die
column19: somtimes you will even see it happen (as much as a virtual novel can without drawing an entire portrait).\nThere are psychotic crazed murders
column20: some characters do have dark backgrounds.\nYou can now remove "furies" from two statues which will be used for world forming
column21: which adds buffs and penalties to you like 30% more EXP and -10% Magic Defense
column22: everyone and every mob deals double damage
column23: or disable your skills
column24:
etc.
I think there are actually multiple endings which came as quite the suprise to me.
You have challenges for each character which will buff their stats like "Lone Fencer" Battle a # of battles alone.

Now lets get to some of the dirty bussiness.

There are indeed still copy paste monster if not at least less.
Sometimes the game just comes out cliche and the timing of some things are inappropriate.
English has barely any lines for combat
column25: you may be listening to "Fang/Pain don't hurt" I don't think any of us can figure out what the ♥♥♥♥ Fang is trying to say
column26:
either way he needs a lesson in grammar.
I like the combat but I can see it getting repetetive for others and you still indeed need to farm extensively but at least world forming will help with that at the same time it seems more difficult to farm.
There are skills that become literally useless further into the game.

Lets get into some more nuetral grounds.
They indeed have removed your ability to change weapons for lore sake but they have replaced it with a system where you equip a second fairy next to your main fairy which resides in your weapon. Anyways this secondary fairy will give you stronger and more passive buffs the more you train them because they do indeed level and I believe cap at 10 though they do take a bit more EXP than most characters.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F is a comedy driven JRPG that plays like Hyperdimension Neptunia but a a little more realistic. The cell shading style is the same and battle system is improved over Hyperdimension. You play a lazy character named Fang who gets thrown into being a Fencer and must collect one hundred Fencer swords to get his wish. The game is a little grind heavy but nothing compared to Maple Story.



Cons I would see is I cannot seem to get the framerate passed 60 to support my 144hz monitor.

reviewText:
An amazing game. Starts off slow, and may seem like a generic Rom/com or Harem Romance Anime story developing.

But as the game progresses, the plot surpasses that generic status, and develops extremely nicely. Each character also is expanded upon to where each of them is percieved as someone with different traits, and backgrounds. It's beautiful.

Every character also provides a different feel in terms of personality and humor that gives dialog variety within the game.

It's like tinder for 2D grills. They keep on showing you options, but in the end, you make the choice for who you want to pursue.

BUT, YOU CAN'T HELP BUT CRY FOR ERYN, DAMN IT.

GET THIS GAME. YOU WON'T REGRET IT.

11/10 ;)

reviewText:
I would describe this as a more polished and complete game than Hyperdimension Neptunia, also a bit more mature.
You get a cliche story with lonely guy meets girl/fairy, and then you get another follower after the other. And then you go and strike the evil powers. Not really an interesting story.

The combat is turn based.

You get base stats + with each level up, along with WP after each fight (Weapon Points to choose to increase i.e p-atk, m-atk or tons with other upgrades and perks/skills),
You can god craft" fairies to tune them to your best use
date: either be it combat where you quip one that gives you bonus skills and stats
recommended: or the special world shaping effect which each fairy will give. You can choose for instance gain 30% more exp
hoursPlayed: but again lose 10% P-ATK. Or get 50% more WP
voteText: but spells costs 2x more to cast. It all differentiate from which "sword/craft" you took from the goddess to boost you fairy.\nEvery fairy you shape comes with one good and one bad perk
helpfulPercent: so you can for instance earn way more exp/gold/stuff with an aggressive setup
votesHelpful: and at normal
votesTotal: you will find out quickly that this game is rather easy
votesFunny: and you want to go all offence.\n\nThe crafting/synthesis is simple
commentsCount: not many materials and patterns
column16: and its easy to find specific materials.\nThe music is also very good and dynamic in combat
column17: it really hits the first times when you "fairize"\n\nThis game is rather unique
column18: and I found it overall highly enjoyable
column19: although the story a bit cliche.\nWould love an even more mature and unique story in the future."

reviewText: I currently have about 6 hours play time with FFF and I have enjoyed every minute of it. I have had a lot of good time playing it tonght and had to pull myself away from it as I am going to have a long day tomorrow.   I highly recommend the game.

reviewText:
If:

* You loved Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 1
* You bought Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 2 immediately afterwards, and loved that one too
* You failed to sign up for the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;birth 3 closed beta by mere minutes
* You watched the first few episodes of the anime to make up for it, but you can't go any further because of spoilers
* You watched the full longplay of the PS3 Hyperdimension Neptunia game (and you were glad that you didn't play that version)
* You still want more of the same, and you want it now
* You are okay with the fact that every single time you activate HD--- I mean, fairize
date: whatever encounter music is playing is replaced by the same cheesy engrish song\n* You are okay with the stares oblique stares about becoming THAT kind of person who plays THAT kind of games\n* You are okay with your favourite Steam tags cementing forever to RPG"
hoursPlayed: "JRPG" and "Cute" (but not with "Female Lead")\n* You hated hunting for hidden items in the Neptunia games
voteText:
especially Re;birth 2
* You are okay with a somewhat more clunky interface
* You are okay with giving up on all the strategy involving guard points and hurtboxes
* You are okay with giving up on the HDD Drive meter carrying over between battles
helpfulPercent: so there's not really a reason not to rush straight for the end of each level\n* You are okay with having to unlock each tier of combo attacks with a hard-to-come-by resource (you need 1
votesHelpful:
000 "weapon points" to unlock the fourth normal attacks in a turn; the final boss is worth 6 WP).
* You were annoyed by the forced losses in Rebirth 1 and instead prefer being yanked out of a perfectly winnable fight only to be treated to a cutscene where your party immediately gives up
* You are okay with bosses announcing their final super-special ultra awesome attack... only to see they usually do two-digit damage.

...then congratulations: Fairy Fencer F is more of the same stuff you liked
votesTotal: and you can stand its most glaring issues. I did
votesFunny: however
commentsCount:
appreciate seeing chirprers being replaced by actual short cutscenes: the more character interaction the merrier.

All in all I really didn't care too much for the changes in actual gameplay and the way plans work in this game is somehow even more infuriating than Hyp-Dim-Nep-Reb (you can't see plans if you don't have any ingredients for it).

Here's a weak "no" from me."

reviewText:
Phenomenal port of Fairy Fencer F. The game supports 1440p, 4k, and ultrawide resolutions. There is a 60fps lock, but you can unlock the framerate via the FairyFencer.ini file. Really optimized compared to the Hyperdimension games, with combat being largely the same except that you have to develop your combos with Weapon Points that you obtain from battles. Dungeons are distinct so you won't be traveling through the same copy/pasted levels. Overall a great RPG.

Bottom line: Hyperdimension with fairies and a male lead.

Superb outta 10.

reviewText:
Pretty solid JRPG. I bought it for the voice cast because the Japanese cast is almost all A or B-list seiyuu and I can even recognize some names in the English cast. The voicework alone justifies the purchase for me.

8/10 PC Port. It's missing:

- Ultrawide support (though props for 4k support)
EDIT: There are some hidden options in the config, but some of them don't seem to do anything.

That doesn't make this a bad port by any means. It still runs smoothly and the gameplay isn't so intensive as to require any more than 60fps.

Also, Tiara best George Foreman grill.

reviewText:
After reading other reviews, I realize that this game could have been amazing if it hadn't been created in Neptunia's shadow. Personally, I didn't care for the HDN games and never got too far into them because the story/characters didn't really interest me.

As for this game, I really loved the characters (except Sherman, more on that later), the artwork is fantastic and it had a nice concept. Even the english VAs aren't too bad though some of the deliveries are poor and the fairies don't have voices in the english option without a workaround. The major downside is the game play.

There's a mechanic in the game where you pull out swords from either the vile god or the goddess using the power of fairys. The furies allow you to obtain abilities and add bonuses to dungeons.

Here's the thing though..Whether or not you pull the furies out of the beings has no impact on the story at all. So the games main mechanic and purpose is basically just pushed off to the side and when you do pull out all the furies you get a wimpy boss that's no different than the end boss.

In fact, If you want any challenge to the game, try not pulling out the furies after the first required to open new dungeons. I had actually skipped the tutorial telling me about world shaping and it didn't occur to me to put more than one fury into the ground until Zepla valley and the only reason I even bothered to at all was for achievement purposes.

That's right. The game is extremely easy if played how it was intended. My first play through was long because I read the story and I ended up playing through two more times because I missed a subevent for a fury piece required to unlock the second to last fairy. These three play through took me at most 30 hrs...So why do I have over 80 hours of play time? Freaking button mashing the last floor of Sudokoos tower while watching tv for the steam achievements.

Yeah. That's right. I did it for the achievements. If I had picked this game up on the PS I wouldn't have cared but seeing those last character achievements locked just bugged me and since I knew I wouldn't be playing this game again I made the dire mistake of saying what the hell" and deciding to just unlock these useless grindy
recommended: as for my dislike of Sherman. His role in the story is useless. He is revealed to be the games main antagonist but he could be replaced by Bernard and the story would've been better. It's revealed that the Vile God's descendants destroyed his family so he attempts to take over the vile Gods powers for..what? It would've been far better if he had joined Fang in his mission to protect Tiara and revive the Goddess. On top of all that
hoursPlayed: somehow being rid of the vile God for good turned into only resealing him and both God and Goddess end up as they were at the start of the story.\n\nOverall
voteText: if you want to pick up this game
helpfulPercent: do it from a bargain bin and do it for the story and characters. Nothing else. I got this game when it was on sale for 55% off and I'm glad I did because it's definitely not a 30 USD worthy game.\n\nI really wish this story/concept had been done in a Tales of Series style. I would also love to play these characters again in a better game
votesHelpful: perhaps a sequel."

reviewText:
So, here we are again, another jrpg game...

Now before I go into detail about certain game elements, I want to tell you that the recommandation is completely biased and you should try to decide for yourself if the game is worth the money or not. Also, you might've noticed I played this game for over 40 hours but I'm not reccomending it, and well, the reasons for that are explained below, if you want to read them.

First of all let's start with the gameplay, it's the usual IF dungeon turn-based combat in which you have certain characters to select from and you make a party of maxium 3 and go beating up monsters and leveling, and all those other elements you'd expect to usually find in a rpg. The combat is alright, and the controls aren't that bad either, considering the guys that made neptunia made this it's bound to be good right...

Next let's talk a little about the story and characters. The story is so blend it makes me puke, it's the usual ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t there's an evil God and a good Goddess and you must revive the goddess and stop the guys who want to ressurect the God, and all that nonsense, seriously, the plot is also a mess, and they try to squeeze in all these elements inside just to cover up for certain plot holes. The easiest element that can do this for you: time travel... And the ending is exactly what you'd expect it to be if you have this kind of stories.

Well, you might be thinking, okay, if the story is bad, maybe the characters might help. Well, the characters are so typical, and tehy're the sterotypes of anime, which is what I hate the most about games such as this, unoriginal character concept is seriously a turnaway. You've got a typical lazy mc who wants to do nothing, two main love interests a tsundere and a yandere, the usual loli, the big boobed chick that's there for fanservice and don't get me started on the fact that there's a cat that talks or whatever that thing is. Now, don't get me wrong, the characters are what they are but there is certain plot development.

Next, let's go in detail about the music and voice acting. The voice acting is decent, I would say good, but that's still not enough to sell this game for what it is, considering the music feels repetitive and every song feels like the other, seriously I'd rather listen to my own songs than to the ingame music at some points.

The final element I'd like to talk about are the achievements, and how insensitive some of them are. Now don't get me wrong, getting the achievements is not a matter of skill but rather a matter of time in this game, with that being said there are a couple of achievements which are if not impossible, then they would take about a couple hundreds of grinding without using any dlc. And even with the dlc they would still take tens of hours to achieve.

Pluses:
-decent gameplay
-well implemented turn based combat
-good voice acting
-skippable animations
Minuses
-overused plot
-stereotypical anime characters
-repetitive music
-mindless grinding

All in all Fairy Fencer F is not a bad game, neither a good one, it's in the middle and everyone can have an opinion about it. Seriously if not for the story and characters this would be a game to remember, but as it is of now, it's all about the grind, and even if you are to finish grinding you would still feel like you achieved nothing...
