reviewText:
When you were a child, did you ever wonder about how your adult life would be? Having grand aspirations on becoming something more than your  parents were, following your own path in life and trying to enjoy yourself within the best of your ability. You would run around at recess playing basketball or playing in the fake metal castle and jungle bars that you gotten hurt from time and time again. Coming home to a warm dinner and greeting your parent or parents and having them ask about your day. The polar opposite could occur, you could have been that weird kid that everyone use to avoid and the teachers didn't know what to do with, you would sit recursively in the corner of the cafeteria, and talk to yourself inside of your head. You would pack a lunch that you made yourself, or if you had lunch tickets that would have to satiate your appetite until the next day, because your family was too poor to offer you any type of sustenance.

No when you came home, it was usually to a house of yelling and throwing things, your mom could have been a junkie your dad an alcoholic and the many brothers and sisters you have, were all so ♥♥♥♥ up beyond belief, they were never home. Your mom could have various men over to feed her habit, and sometimes these men would molest you, and so would your father after a stupor. This type of child had no chance in life. These children are brought into the world to do nothing but suffer. They play escapism in their minds to ease the pain that they are in. The only remedy for them would be to take them out of that hostile environment and place them with a truly kind family.

Child 1 would exhibit some issues, but for the most part he would live a pretty decent life, giving the fact he/she would have the social skills and the support that they need to push on through. If not brought up properly they would proceed to become entitled and have this persisting narcissistic personality disorder. Nothing would ever be enough and everything that bad ever happened would be others fault.  So while both children would have these things in their minds growing up, child 1 for the most part would be extremely more likely to succeed instead of child 2, who would developed a multitude of mental illnesses, where they couldn't cope with for the rest of their lives.

I have witnessed both of these things growing up, while attending school. You could always tell the children who were damaged and the children that had a pretty much life of leisure. I fall somewhere between child 1 and child 2, a mixture of real bad ♥♥♥♥, and real good ♥♥♥♥. A loving home, but also a broken home. A sheltered childhood, rampant with violence and chaos outside, filled with children growing up way to fast, and running dope on the street, like it's some sort of normalcy for them. My house was filled with a lot of fighting, arguing and general malignancy from many family members. A loving mother, grandmother and aunt, protecting me from the harms of the real world and the neighborhood. I spent most of my childhood indoors in front of the TV playing video games that my mom or grandmother would rent for me at blockbuster, I had a five dollar a week allowance that I could spend on whatever I wanted.

We were very poor, but we always had the lights on, food on the table, and a roof over our heads. My mother and grandmother would buy me the latest consoles even if I had to wait a bit, they would put layaway's and surprise me at birthdays and Christmas, my mom would write little sayings in my book bag for valentines day saying how much she loved me, and my grandmother would always cooked what I wanted for thanksgiving and Christmas. I had many good memories and many bad memories, but these three women always tried within the best of their ability to always make sure that I was always taking care of. I always had new clothes throughout the school year, and I always use to go to parks with my aunt because as said earlier the neighborhood was too bad to venture outside. I was hated throughout elementary school because I wasn't like most children. I use to get terrorized on the bus and made fun of because my hobbies included listening to music and playing video games. I was picked on for being overweight, and for being to proper and respectful.  Teachers were always antagonistic towards me, because I was the kid always questioning things, as to make them feel like it's more work for them, as oppose to enlightening a young mind.

I would go through middle school and high school pretending to be something I am not. I would dress in my own style that consisted over various name brand clothing, I would always get the latest shoes  and colognes and I would put of this mask of someone who is wealthy and happy. I gave my mom and grandmother a lot of stress during this time, we didn't have the money to keep up this image and I would get into fights with them about it. I was popular, I hung out with people who made quadruple my mothers income, they would ride around in Mercedes and BMW, while my mom had this rinkydink Buick from the late 80s. I was ashamed of her jobs that she took to support me, and ashamed of where I lived and the cars that my family had. I tried everything to the best of my ability to make sure no one found out. I was loved, people knew who I was, they wanted to be me, they wanted to be able to be what I was. Girls were actually intimidated by me, come to find out later on, the reason I had such a hard time dating was because of the fact that these girls didn't think I would take it seriously and feared rejection.

I'm not tooting my own horn, I began to hate what I have become, what I was, what I was turning into. It was fake, I was a fraud, I was everything every kid wanted to be in middle school and high school, but I was horribly depressed. Until one day I couldn't take it anymore, and It caught up to me. In the middle of high school I had an immunity disorder, for some unknown reason I would get sick every week. I missed more than a 120 days of school. I had bronchitis, mono, flu, strep, pulled groin, dislocated knee, walking pneumonia, I had it ♥♥♥♥ing all. During this time my grades were awful, I mean they always were terrible, but they really tanked. A little after summer, and after 9/11 I didn't attend school, I was majorly depressed and wouldn't leave my room, by this time I moved into a better neighborhood and things were a bit different. Like I said though, I stayed in my room all day and finally I was expelled for missing too many days. That was it, it was over, my so called friends forgot about me, and my popularity meant jackshit. I would suffer from this for an obscene amount of time.

From that point on things didn't get better they just got worse and worse. At the end of 2011 I was hoping for a better year, I've been reclusive and working the job I still work at till this day that I hate, but at the end of 2011 I was hoping that I would finally have a good year, that this is the year that I would make a change. 2012 comes in, off to the same start as any other year, my grandmother had her 75th birthday, and I was as close as ever to her, till late March, where she got sick, she was hospitalized and had two mini strokes and passed away, 2013 would come and my uncle would be hospitalized with the same issues my grandmother had, he would last one more years and die in October of 2014. Every year since 2012 had been the worst years of my life, 2013 was particular horrible, but that's a bit too personal to get into, so lets just say it was just purely awful.

It's 2016 right now, and I am terribly unhappy, and have difficulty living each day. My heart is broken to a million pieces because I miss my grandmother and uncle so ♥♥♥♥ing much. So take it from me, just live life the best you can and share it with others who cherish and deserve your love.

reviewText:
g-SCORE: [1.8]

Fairy Fencer F turned out to be a fun title, but did not have enough pull for me. I liked the Anime style comedy and dialogue, but the combat and progression just didn't keep me interested.

g-Rating Categories:

>>gameplay [1]
The game is basically dialogue and combat. There is no exploration really. You unlock different areas of the map as you progress, but they are stand-alone dungeons. The dialogue was great as was the Anime-style humor, but I couldn't get into the combat. It's turn-based inside an encounter" arena that lets you move around to position before attacking or performing some other action. I think a more traditional turn-based RPG encounter mechanic would have been better (no movement) because the camera got in the way and honestly I didn't find the positioning to offer much variety from a strategic perspective. It was basically move >> attack
date:
move >> attack.

>>graphics [2]
The dungeons were very bland and generic
recommended:
but the cutscenes and character art were awesome.

>>gui [2]
I played with a keyboard mostly. Although there were times when I had to use the mouse because sometimes keys were not mapped to some actions (like selecting a character to heal).

>>glitches [3]
Solid. No bugs.

>>gasp [1]
I'd rather watch an Anime.

Best possible score is a [3.2]."

Cons:

Overall this was a hell of a game. Would I recommend? What kind of silly question is that? Of course I recommend!

reviewText:
This game is pretty disappointing in every way you can imagine.
Lackluster dungeons with the most simplified designs possible, it’s not even an issue of the graphics being dated, that’s understandable. The issue is that they drew up these maps in about 30 seconds and said “we’re good to go!”   By the way I just checked and this game came out originally in 2013! WTF! Xenoblade Chronicles came out in 2010 and for an inferior console and it looks about a billion times better than this!
-
Extremely simplified turn based combat, it’s all about keeping healthy and doing more damage, no crazy strategies here. If the game wants to give you a tougher boss they don’t actually come up with an interesting boss that will keep you guessing, instead they just do more damage and take less damage, quite simple and uninspiring.
-
A story that on paper seems like they could have done something good with it but in reality there is no story here, just an intro, and a bunch of clichéd fan service crap and cookie cutter bad guys.
-
Oh, btw, there’s no walking into towns, digesting beautiful sceneries, exploring and adventuring, etc.  Oh no, this game was made in power point, it’s just slides of text after slides of text with anime girls in questionable outfits and when you think you are done and you can go out and explore the world, all there is for you is a menu and several options to choose from before going to your next lame dungeon, there’s not even a real world map. There is but you can’t walk around it and fight monsters in it, it’s just a screen where you move a cursor to pick which dungeon to go into.
-
There is one thing that does make this game playable (barely) and that is the dialogue. 99% of the dialogue in this game is excrement but that 1% can be hilarious in ways you haven’t laughed in a game for a long long time.

My recommendation is don’t buy this horrible excuse for a JRPG and buy The Legend of Heroes Trails in The Sky instead (it’s on steam and it’s an incredible, incredible game)
But if you must play it, do yourself a favor and buy the armor pack DLC that costs less than a dollar, that way you can breeze through bosses and finish this game as quickly as possible so you don’t keep hurting yourself.

OH, and a very important thing. If you are like me, married with family and happen to play your videogames at night when the wife sleeps, on the big screen TV with headphones, make sure she is very deeply asleep because my wife wakes up in the middle of the night and sees the tv and goes “oh, playing the witcher? Cool, have fun!” and goes back to sleep.
It’s not cool when she wakes up and sees cartoon gigantic boob dangling around the screen.
Scratch that… 13 year old gigantic boobs and then looks at you with a “did I marry a serial killer ♥♥♥♥♥♥ pederast Hitler?!?!?”


AVOID PAIN, AVOID THIS GAME.

reviewText:
I found this game to be interesting to say the least. Once one figures out how to skip around the majority of useless talking then it's not half bad.
There are several key point which should be made however, key among them is the rather lacking travel system and places to explore. City navigation was reduced to a menu rather than walking around a city or town itself. The dungeons were repetative and by most game standards highly incomplete. I would even go as far as to say that the game itself is incomplete. There are many, many opportunities to miss things which one would think would be required to actually complete the game. This also doesn't even factor into account that your main goal is to pull all of the swords out of this goddess, of which you can't even achieve on the first play through. There is no real rpg aspect to the game as you do not have any real choices to make, you cannot influence the real out come of the game. The ending is set, though they did offer three different ones based on one conversation only (which means, you either talked to this person or that, not giving you a choice in any conversations is what this game is all about it seems).
There are only two ways to make playing and fighting in this game slightly enjoyable and relaxing. The first is to cheat with some form of hex editor and modify your xp and skill points. The second is to spend hours upon hours of grinding. The story line is a B at best, maybe a C+, it's nothing short of what a middle school student could have written for a short story.
The fighting system was passable, but left no room for diversity or customization of characters. The best thing about this game was the few tid bits of costume which you could place on different characters.

For my rating I will give the following on a 1-5 scale, 1 being the worst:
Graphics 3
Game play ease 4
Rpg / options 1
Story line 2
Replayability 1
Diversity 2
Over all 2

If you want some thing quick and lacking thinking then this is right up your alley. It requires no brain power or creativity what so ever.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F is a strange game.

On one hand, some top-tier talents were involved in it's production (Yoshitaka Amano and Nobuo Uematsu of Final Fantasy fame, and Tsunako, the illustrator of the Neptunia games), and it shows in some ways, like it having some very catchy musical themes and appealing character designs.

On the other hand, despite all the promise the names give, this is still a very generic JRPG, with party members, turn-based battles, cliche'd characters, tons of grinding, and overly long visual novel-esque character banters. These don't make this game bad by themselves, but because they are not implemented in any stand-out way, the game overall feels only mediocre.

The first 20 hours of the game are decent, as you constantly obtain new party members and dungeons to grab your interest. However, after those initial 20 hours, you reach a point where the battles and dungeons start to constantly repeat themselves, and even though the story is far from over, with so few unique things to hook you to the game, it eventually becomes a boring grindfest.

I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't as it doesn't bring anything new and exciting to the table, just recycles familiar genre traditions, with nothing but a bit of polish and very little charm.

I won't recommend it to you unless you crave for about 20 hours of decent content (about a half of the game), and find it at a very steep discount.

reviewText:
While I appreciate that there's a drought of good jRPGs on PC, you have to understand - this game has EXTREMELY low production values. I haven't played the game to completion and I don't plan to. Maybe it gets better later, but I doubt it.

You know how most jRPGs feature towns that you can run around and talk to the denizens? Nope. None of that here. Here the town (the only town as far as I can tell after what I played) is basically a menu.

You know how most jRPGs feature either cutscenes or in-engine scenes for important events? Nope. None of that here. You just get VN-style talking heads.

You know how in most jRPGs dungeons feature gameplay other than random battles, such as solving puzzles and discovering interesting lore and useful items? Nope. Dungeons are extremely bland here. At least not as far as I got, which may not be a lot, but it's the point where most other games in the genre have opened up a bit.

You know how RPGs are defined y the characters you meet, and so most strive to have good ones? Nope. So far all the characters have been so incredibly onedimensional, it's almost criminal.

You know how the plot is *the* most important thing in an RPG? Noooope. No plot here. At least so far. Move along.

All in all, buy something else.

reviewText:
Fairy Fencer F

TL:DR Summary;
Don't believe the rating of the game - you need to make your own judgement call before buying.
Don't like grindfests? Don't buy this game -  You like grindfests? then buy this game.

The characters themselves are created extremely well, to the usual highest of standards and fit well within the storylines.  Fang though comes across far too whiny in the early parts of the game though but at least, the other characters are hilarious especially Eryn and Tiara who no doubt will replace Nep as someones waifu.

Tiara and Eryn both are amazing characters, the voice actors do really amazing jobs in capturing their often hilirious quirks, such as Tiara strange kinky responses when shes verbally assalted by fang.  Both character design is perfect,  the other characters are all fairly well balanced too but don't nearly stand out as much as Tiara and Eryn.

A great game but has a really poorly designed questing system which forces the player into loading/reloading dungeons countless number of times in order to get rare drops in order to synthesis stones to complete rank quests, these quests are extremely grindfest and incredibly frustrating especially if you get unlucky with crappy RNG, and to make matters worse these Collector Quests just get worse as you rank up,  Rank C is pretty bad - I shudder to think how bad Rank B and A will be,  but these shouldn't be designed this way - Compile Heart you disappoint me here,  you're better than this to throw in a really unnessary grindfest in order to progress your questing.

Some stones are somewhat 'easy' to find with Item Sonar as they as the potential areas are close to the entrance, like with the ice cave so the re-loading of the dungeon isn't so bad, but other dungeons on the other hand, the hidden treasure could be far away and that takes a significant amount of time finding the hidden treasure, and thats even 'assuming' its not a useless sprout inside.    Basically, if there is a DLC or any cheat/feature that clearly displays the hidden treasure on the map immediately without having to use item sonar, then this is clearly NEEDED in order to keep your sanity after your 1000th dungeon reload and you still haven't gotten your stupid stones yet.

Clearly, this quest system just doensn't work very well at all, and unfortunately this heavily impacts the games fun factor once the tedium sets in.  Compile Hearts, please do not do this again with future releases - stick with the tried and tested methods that worked with the HDN series.

As for the rest of the game, I haven't had any issues - everything else is good.  Good characters,  good story lines with humorous dialogue and the voice acting is up to high standards.   The graphics and drawing are on par with the HDN series.

Whilst I honestly enjoy the game, and story - I just can't get past the mistakes made with the quest system, and thats the only - repeat ONLY reason for the not recommend review.   *IF* you don't mind a more hardcore approach to grinding and farming, especialy farming for stones so you can synthesis then you will enjoy Fairy Fencer F,  if your like me and have no patience at all these days for farming and/or get easily frustrated then I would do more research first before buying into this game.

Closing statements here is that the worst problems that Fairy Fencer F suffers from are insane grinds require for portions of the game, especially in farming for stones and stealing quest items which have a very very low success rate.   Another minor issue is that halfway though the game, the difficulty unusually spikes with monsters doing alot more damage, plus you'll face more in battles + boss battles get more intense, I'll not reveal anymore information on this because it'll potentially spoil it for anyone reading, but the spike feels like it wasn't tested enough and makes an already grindy game, feel even more grindy.

Alot of content is also highly missable, such as recruiting extra characters which first time around, is more or less impossible and really aimed at NG+ so expect to play through multiple times in order to unlock alot of the extras.  Finally, if anyone doesn't believe me about the drop rates being really bad - just check the forums yourself and read all the posts regarding this - Don't take accept anyone saying that they are 'fine' because they are clearly not.

Whilst reading through my review and reading through peoples responses, I think I came off as highly critical.  I make no real apologies here since everyone has their own right to post how they feel about any game they play, whether its a hateful comments or because they just really love the game and cannot stand any negativity.  However,  I think I was wrong to give this game a 5/10 and I will admit, that was a mistake - however, my previous statements I will still standby them.

Overall 6/10

++ Slick combat system
++ Good WP system for developing characters skill and abilities
++ Cute and Moe Characters
++ Great Storyline and Dialogue
+++ Music Score by legendary Nobuo Uematsu

- Highly missable content
-- DLC heavy
-- Too much emphasis on farming
-- Some side quests and synthesis feels grindy
---Major grindfest in certain areas of the game
---Collectors quests has a long and unnecessary grind

I'm kind of a hard core RPG player and just like anyone who plays RPGs I always have my skepticisms about a game I pick up. Being an enthusiast about Anime didn't have anything to do with my review. I will say that this game is incredibly detailed. The developement of the characters was meticulously thought through and the interactions of the characters don't change for the sake of story developement. All characters are very different and very in personality. The idea of time and it's affect on the world when the particular sequence appears is actually quite accurate. Any change in a timeline can have the potential to change everything about the time stream that you currently travel which is why I believe it was a well thought out paradigm of the story. With the inclusion of the choice of Good or Evil makes this an interesting blend and includes several even more interesting character interations. Players don't necessarily have to grind to finish the game, but it does certainly help. The idea of overkilling enemies has always been a thing for me and with the DLC added to the game, adds the possibility of total annihilation. Getting certain materials to create new weapons, armor, items, misc. items, and other synthesis materials is difficult but if it were easy then it wouldn't be worth the effort. The synthesis items are much stronger than what you can buy and If you farm the materials then it is worth that much more. I would say to be careful about the boss battles when reviving the God or Goddess. If you have the DLC it is easier than normal, however once you reach a certain rank they will start getting though your armor so don't rely on the DLC to last you the whole game. It wont. Overall I recommend this game to any and all RPG enthusiasts out there even if you don't like Anime. It is a rich story full of spontanious and often hilarious conversations. I enjoy the game and I hope anyone who has just gotten or even just thinking about getting it will too.

Enjoyable for the first few hours, but I was left feeling more and more disappointed as it went on.

If you like Hyperdimention Neptunia then you will like this game, if you didn't like Neptunia's combat mechanics then this would not be for you. It's a lot, a lot, of conversations that are somewhat amusing, but the game does allow you to skip them if your not into the story and just like the combat or have already played through once and listened to the many hours of story already, it's always nice when games don't force the story on you (specailly when your playing through a game a second time). And the combat is Exactly like Hyperdimintion Neptunia which was an interesting idea, and enjoyable, but could be finiky aiming with controller and a bit less finiky but still finiky with mouse and keyboard.

Story seems like most JRPGs, amussing but pretty bad at the same time, kind of like good bad movies for example the first Mortal Kombat movie was a bad movie but good at the same time because it was that cheesy bad.

All in all if you like JRPGs you will probably like this, but expect to get a bit frustrated trying to aim a conal attack at two enemies every once in a while but otherwise enjoyable combat, expect amusingly bad dialog (and a lot of it), and expect to have to grind in the late game (not certain on that, but most JRPGs end up grindy mid way through).

Idea Factory, it seems that they can't get away from making there games similar to Hyperdimension in almost every aspect, at least that's what it felt like to me after playing several hours of Fairy Fencer F. The game is as Turn based JRPG that follows the standard premise for JRPG's but does a few things different from the sandard.

I'll start with the story, the idea is that two gods (The vile god and the Goddess)had a falling out and paralized each other with each others swords. The swords that missed ended up in the world, embedded in the ground waiting for a capable human to pull them out. When someone pulls one out, the Fairy within the weapon is bound to them at that moment and it allows the person to weild incredible power. These people then become Fencer's, people who can weild these weapons and the fairies within them. Almost every goal for a Fencer is to collect 100 Furies (The weapons with fairies) and pull all the swords out of the goddess and in doing so, they will be granted a wish. So yeah, it follows a very obvious premise to JRPG's, having Gods, a single corporation that turns out to be evil behind the scene's and so on. So the story isn't very original in it's idea but it does do a couple of things different then other JRPG's.

Next is the combat and if you've played any of the Hyperdimension Re;birth games then it's going to feel very similar, and by similar I mean it's the exact same as the Re;birth games. You have up to three characters on the battlefield and you move each one when it's there turn within a specific area. You can start off with a basic attack which will start your combo for that characters turn, but you start off with only one and have to increase your combos by aquiring them with weapon points. Just like Hyperdimension you can switch you attacks anytime you want for different one's which allows you to mix and match a lot of different attacks to find one's that go together. Your skills contain two catagories, Skills and magic. Skills are a combination of magic attacks with physical attacks and Magic is pretty self expainitory. Next is Fairize, this is your characters transformation allowing them to use the power of there Fairy to increase there stats and gives access to a unique skill. To access the transformation, there will a bar connected to the characters portait in the top right corner, when this bar fills up (By taking damage or dealing damage) and glows blue, you can access the transformation which gives the character an increase in there physical  attack and defense, but will start to decrease if you take damage. The transformation is nice but it can be turned off so easily that it'll barely last for a couple of turns if your getting beat and the increase in stats is quite minimal that you probably might not even notice the difference. Next, every character has a unique ability tied to them that they can only use, Fang has serious face (Well named there) which gives him a big increase in physical attack by 2.0 but his base attacks cost SP and his skills SP usage will also increase by 1.5. Tiara has a protective barrier that will only pretect her but can withistand really strong attacks and Harley has the ability to scan enemys and exposse there weaknesses. At the end of it, it's rather slick and fastpased, the animations look really smooth and the partical effects and skills look really good, the transformation could look better though.

The one thing I've always praised Idea Factory for is the art design. Be it with this game or Hyperdimension, the character models, the sceneary and the enviroment look beautiful and very well done. They're always so full of color and never look over designed.

On to the last thing that really kinda takes me away from the game and that is the characters themselves, I find it very difficult to stay interested in a game where most of the characters are so unbearable that I want to punch them in there face. I'll start with our main protagonist Fang, an egotistic, big headed, arrogent, slightly selfish food lover. It's difficult for me to find a place for me to start with him since I have a fair amount of problems with him. The things he's says seem only to elevate his own opinion of himself and has a distinct habit of down right insulting the other characters for no reason which makes it very difficult for me to feel anything for him when he acts like that. The rest of them have a habit of responding to a situation or each other in the most piculiar way that doesn't really make any sense, but some of them have had effort in putting personalities into them. It is nice however to see a male protagonist who isn't a cliced angsty teenager but the way they did it doesn't make him likeable in many ways, An example I can give for a good male protagonist in a video game is Yuri Lowell, I recommend looking for yourself why but I digress.

You may have noticed that I've been comparing this to Idea Factoy's other game Hyperdimension a lot and that is because it is practically the same game but with different characters and setting. The problem I find however, if I where to compare it to Hyperdimension, is that it doesn't have the charm or the personality that Hyperdimension has. That has many different characters with different personalities that suit there character designs for one, the other being that it just doesn't care, it will constantly break the fourth wall, refence other games and hardware, poke fun at the game industry and at animes. It has that charm to it that makes it enjoyable and fun to the point where you'll spend hours paying attention to the dialogue just to see what they'll reference next and what thing within the game industry they'll poke fun at, I mean come on, at the begining of Re;birth 3 they reference the Oculus Rift and Sword art online by creating a device called the Nepulus gift" (Something like that) and having it looking exactly like the Nerv gear. The list goes on and one with what they'll do.

I digress

While not the most original RPG out there it does have its moments. They did a decent balance of humor with the story albeit very predictably. The ferrize thing though is just way over the top, but ignoring that and the fact they did it that way on purpose for the story and humor it is worth playing. I mostly enjoyed the interatctions between Tiara and Fang. And the side story with Apollonius wasn't bad, but I wish they did more with it. Don't get me started on the weird guy in the animal suit... Story wise the main complaint I had is the way the handled the main town. The conversations with the locals were all pointless and did not really endear you with the story, but personally I felt like I had to read it in case there was some subplot that would show up.... sadly they did not really take advanatage of that and no quests from any of the common characters ever occured.

Gameplay itself is pretty mediocre. Reason I say that is because really pretty much through 95% of the game I was just spamming attack + skip, ferrize + skip, attack + skip. This game definitely did not focus on strategy. Most of the time I got through battles without losing any characters because I just focused on stunning the monsters with combos so I would end up getting the game to trigger the event to get other party members to get a whack in. This even worked on bosses. I would generally advise not to buy the DLC that provides the armors unless you want to have two characters be nearly invulnerable for 60-75% of the storyline game. I'm telling you those armors are way overpowered! Don't get me started on the other DLC's where if you want the stat boost at all your characters are in towels?!?!

Now the one thing I really do have to say was a decent idea for the battlesystem and that was the combos mechanic. It really did let me choose a moveset that I could get the maximum amount of damage. The main problem with the combo system is due to how much time it takes to play thing game (and how much I was spamming skip) I ended up only using the same moveset over and over and ignoring any of the other possibilities because 90% of the time the moveset I chose for the A button worked, so there was no reason to choose any of the other choices. I never really used any magics at all except for healing as it wasted more time than it was worth in most cases.

Lastly the questing system at the bar is seemingly pointless. The amount of griding that is needed is rather sad. The rewards do not even cover the time spent on the task in many cases. Once you get to the C important mission I was stuck for a long time because I didn't check to see if there was a way to synth the ingredient.. figured I would pick it up somewhere.... wrong.

Bottom line I would rate the game as a C

Story C+
Gameplay D
Amount of Gameplay A-

If you're bored I would recommend it, but there are better choices out there such as Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky

This was the best game I played this year, hands down. Unlike the NepNep games, I actually hadn't played FFF when it originally came out. So, where to start...

For starters - if you like anime - this is probably more up your alley than NepNep. It has a much more serious tone yet still retains that sense of humor. It reads well. The plot is (mostly) solid. All-in-all, it was enjoyable.

I like all the characters. Fang shows character development. Something which is largely absent from NepNep. Tiara and Eyrn do as well. Actually, all of them show character development. I guess that's part of what I liked too. Fang goes from a lazy bum who just wants to eat ♥♥♥♥ to a guy who gets ♥♥♥♥ done. As far as characters go - my favorite list goes something like Ethel, Eyrn, Tiara, Fang, Harley, Pippin...

This game leaves quite a bit unanswered. If you're an inquisitive sort, this game will wreck you. I find myself wanting to know some details which just weren't explained. Which is to say, most things don't leave me wanting answers. I'm hoping the sequel sheds some light on these.

There are some negatives. No game is perfect, of course.

Some battles felt forced and lacked sense. I'm largely referring to the forced losses, which I feel it would be better if they just did story segments for some of them. With FFF, half the time I destroyed my MP meter only to get obliterated next phase when I actually *can* win the fight and it isn't a forced loss. It's too hard to tell the impossible battles from non-impossible. For example, before the final battle, the Marianne fight. During forced loss, she has three dots. You get her down to one, and then it RESTARTS, and she has six dots on her meter and it's Fang only. Seriously. Kinda unfair.

TL;DR - Best thing I played this year, but does have some flaws. Oh, and Ethel is the best. Also, Pippin = Excalibur

Note - I'm a Linux user, and I maintain the AppDB page for FFF on WineHQ. This game doesn't work perfectly on Wine at the moment. If you have a Windows computer, just do yourself a favor and buy it. It'll work well on Wine sooner than later, and you shouldn't skip this.

A great game with nice gameplay mechanics, a great storyline buildup, a lot of moving moments, an amazing climax AAAAAND...

... the lamest endings in the history of the RPG genre.

Seriously, I wouldn't even bother trying to replay the lengthy sections you have to replay in order to get all of them unless you're in it for the achievements (there's a breakpoint in the story where you get to choose what ending you'll get through a single decision, so you can save before that point and choose your route). All you'll get is a static background image for each ending, which will contain like five unique dialogue lines, completely unsatisfactory and bland compared to what the story was being so far. Get one and watch the other two on YouTube, there are plenty of non-commentary gameplays showing only the endings in Auto mode.

Despite my tremendous disappointment with the ending, the game is solid and worth replaying at least once, since NG+ isn't exactly the same as the first playthrough, there are a couple of surprises in there. I recommend it, especially if you're a grinding maniac who wants to get to level 999 and collect every item, you'll get a lot of hours of entertainment for the price while rarely getting bored.

This game is the very definition of a lot of Japanese RPGs since 2005. Mediocre and completely soulless. It's not bad and it's hardly good either. It's average, ordinary, undistinguished, middle-of-the-road, lackluster, forgettable and other synonyms related to second-rate.

Characters are common stereotypes found in many Japanese media directed towards teenagers such as in animes and mangas. Here's some examples:

1) The hot-blooded but borderline mentally ret-rded" MC.
2) The "cutesy but sometimes annoying" female lead.
3) The "tsundere pseudo-noble lady" rival of female lead to be the best girl.
4) The "one who exist solely as fanservice" supporting female lead.

There are a few more characters but if you're familiar with animes and mangas

reviewText: The story is funny especially that time when the protagonist pronounce fairize

If you're a gamer that is into the JRPG genre, turn-based battling, visual novels, beautifully drawn anime and background art and hours on end of quests, leveling, skill customization and fairies then Fairy Fencer F is for you. I can't remember the last time I power played an RPG as thoroughly as this one.

I have gone through two playthroughs already and going for a third to get my last ending. Japanese and English voice acticing are amazingly done, though if you choose to hear the game in Japanese you will be treated to some extra voiced content when viewing some Sub-Events back in town. While the game is not punishingly difficult and never posing much of a challenge with the main storyline, there is a degree of challenge present in the sidequests to keep things from being a boring button masher.

Word of advice to completionists not wanting to miss anything on their first playthrough, upon entering a new dungeon and viewing the cutscene, leave immediately and go back to town and accept Lola's quests as they are time sensitive. Try to fight every enemy you see at least once, inspect the maps throroughly to look out for diamonds containing possibly missable loot and obtain the Item Sonar ability as soon as you can.

Overall I recommend this game highly to any JRPG fan that is into a good story filled with likeable characters with a great balance of drama, action and comedy.

This was the best game I played this year, hands down. Unlike the NepNep games, I actually hadn't played FFF when it originally came out. So, where to start...

For starters - if you like anime - this is probably more up your alley than NepNep. It has a much more serious tone yet still retains that sense of humor. It reads well. The plot is (mostly) solid. All-in-all, it was enjoyable.

I like all the characters. Fang shows character development. Something which is largely absent from NepNep. Tiara and Eyrn do as well. Actually, all of them show character development. I guess that's part of what I liked too. Fang goes from a lazy bum who just wants to eat ♥♥♥♥ to a guy who gets ♥♥♥♥ done. As far as characters go - my favorite list goes something like Ethel, Eyrn, Tiara, Fang, Harley, Pippin...

This game leaves quite a bit unanswered. If you're an inquisitive sort, this game will wreck you. I find myself wanting to know some details which just weren't explained. Which is to say, most things don't leave me wanting answers. I'm hoping the sequel sheds some light on these.

There are some negatives. No game is perfect, of course.

Some battles felt forced and lacked sense. I'm largely referring to the forced losses, which I feel it would be better if they just did story segments for some of them. With FFF, half the time I destroyed my MP meter only to get obliterated next phase when I actually *can* win the fight and it isn't a forced loss. It's too hard to tell the impossible battles from non-impossible. For example, before the final battle, the Marianne fight. During forced loss, she has three dots. You get her down to one, and then it RESTARTS, and she has six dots on her meter and it's Fang only. Seriously. Kinda unfair.

TL;DR - Best thing I played this year, but does have some flaws. Oh, and Ethel is the best. Also, Pippin = Excalibur

Note - I'm a Linux user, and I maintain the AppDB page for FFF on WineHQ. This game doesn't work perfectly on Wine at the moment. If you have a Windows computer, just do yourself a favor and buy it. It'll work well on Wine sooner than later, and you shouldn't skip this.
Great jrpg! I would recommend this game to anyone who likes the genre. Once again Compile Heart does great work. Only downside is the grindiness of some of the quests and a couple achievements.

date: you got sent back in time and you gotta do everything over again so you get girl." And boy

hoursPlayed: it seems like it's actually sub-plot. That said this is the story of a lazy boy named Fang who prefers slack off in bed or eating Bahus' cooking and he is roped into reviving the Goddess by circumstance (and lots of peer pressure). And that's basically the gist of it.\n\nOnto gameplay. At first glance I thought this game would live up to the brutal difficulty of Re;Birth but it sadly didn't. However
voteText: I later realized that the game was designed to be played a certain way. And that is by stabbing furies various place in the world map and making use of what is called "world shaping". Let me give you the quick rundown. World shaping is an ability that fairies use when they are stabbed on the ground. They have a certain radius that are dictated by their level. Let's say that a fairy has a world shaping ability of -10% P.DEF and +10% M.ATK. This means that every creature in that dungeon (including you) have their physical defense decreased by 10% while all magical attacks are 10% stronger. There are various world shaping effects that help increase damage (taken and delivered)

reviewText: Pretty funny and enjoyable JRPG. Nothing else to say that others didn't already. If you played any of their Hyperdimension Neptunia, then you know what to expect.

I'll be brief. Fairy Fencer F is fun. A lot of fun. Except when it gets grindy (doing a couple of sidequests and getting a secret character on the first playthrough come to mind), but it's still fun. A bit on the easy side, as far as the combat is concerned, but nevertheless fun. I found myself laughing out loud at some of the dialogues. Make sure you use the Japanese voices, though.

10/10. I highly recommend this game to any and all JRPG fans. It is a bit on the shorter side, but has tons of replayabilty. The character art is great, as are the characters themselves. The english voices are passable (except for one character) and the option to change languages at almost any time is very welcomed. The music is generally very good (except for one track that I personally was not a fan of). The graphics are not the most spectacular on the market, but are still quite good.
The game is a MUST have if you like turn base'd RPG :D

Only a very short way into the game so far, but if the rest of the game plays out like the beginning, then this is a title worthy checking out for any of you who enjoy a good jrpg.

The controls are simple and well explained.
The art is (in my opinion) very good
The battles are fun
The voice acted dialogs are humorous

All in all, I have to recommend this to rpg fans.

I bought the came out of boredom. Didn't think I'd like it this much. I find that this game can definately pull you in if your into rpgs otherwise you wouldn't be reading reviews. Also the time on record I put in was literally in two days since I just couldn't put it down. Now go out there buy this get some laughs and enjoy the game.

For people who liked Hyper Dimension Neptunia, this is a must buy . To be fair, I've had my playthroughs of final fantasy and other rpgs, so to me, this turned to be more interactive and strategic than most . There's plenty I like about the game, but a few others I dislike. I'll start with what I like :D

Positive
- Funny, not too many games that introduce a humorous cast of characters actually make me smile and laugh.
- Beautiful art style and anime, characters look and act how they were made
- Easy combat system, items, attack, combos and spells pretty generic but very satisfying to see those combo strings and multiple damage hits
- Basic but fair storyline, very generic and simplistic story to follow and understand

Negatives
- Rushed, many of the characters are thrown into your way and then into your party about 2 minutes after you meet them without even really understanding why or who the hell they are
- Repetative; its a very simple system: go to town, events, buy info, free swords, go into dungeon, grind/complete quests (repeat) the side quests and events are really the only thing besides the storyline you can do
- Very short dungeons (also a pro) The dungeons are usually consisted of less than 5 areas, you can complete the main quest in a matter of minutes
- Protagonist (also a pro) I may get anime people jumping on back for this lol: the protagonist made me laugh and he does grow and develop throughout the game, but its just a hero I cannot get behind and makes me strongly dislike him later in the story. The early part had me laughing, but later on had me facepalming, honestly I wished  Sherman was the main protagonist, thats my opinion though lol.
- Brief tutorials, while most people generically know what their doing; its a little bit of a slap in the face that Eryn's tutorials pop up for like 3 screens going , yeah this is how you do this and this
date: good luck finding  these matierals yada yada. " The game doesn't tell you where you can get specific items or materials.\n\nI still play the game and I still haven't finished the main story
recommended: so I'm no expert whatsoever; however this is a very fun game to play and kill time. The art style
hoursPlayed: the graphics and the gameplay are very fun . I'd play this when you get a lot of time and feel for a simplistic set back style game."

If you're a gamer that is into the JRPG genre, turn-based battling, visual novels, beautifully drawn anime and background art and hours on end of quests, leveling, skill customization and fairies then Fairy Fencer F is for you. I can't remember the last time I power played an RPG as thoroughly as this one.

I have gone through two playthroughs already and going for a third to get my last ending. Japanese and English voice acticing are amazingly done, though if you choose to hear the game in Japanese you will be treated to some extra voiced content when viewing some Sub-Events back in town. While the game is not punishingly difficult and never posing much of a challenge with the main storyline, there is a degree of challenge present in the sidequests to keep things from being a boring button masher.

Word of advice to completionists not wanting to miss anything on their first playthrough, upon entering a new dungeon and viewing the cutscene, leave immediately and go back to town and accept Lola's quests as they are time sensitive. Try to fight every enemy you see at least once, inspect the maps throroughly to look out for diamonds containing possibly missable loot and obtain the Item Sonar ability as soon as you can.

Overall I recommend this game highly to any JRPG fan that is into a good story filled with likeable characters with a great balance of drama, action and comedy.

A great game with nice gameplay mechanics, a great storyline buildup, a lot of moving moments, an amazing climax AAAAAND...

... the lamest endings in the history of the RPG genre.

Seriously, I wouldn't even bother trying to replay the lengthy sections you have to replay in order to get all of them unless you're in it for the achievements (there's a breakpoint in the story where you get to choose what ending you'll get through a single decision, so you can save before that point and choose your route). All you'll get is a static background image for each ending, which will contain like five unique dialogue lines, completely unsatisfactory and bland compared to what the story was being so far. Get one and watch the other two on YouTube, there are plenty of non-commentary gameplays showing only the endings in Auto mode.

Despite my tremendous disappointment with the ending, the game is solid and worth replaying at least once, since NG+ isn't exactly the same as the first playthrough, there are a couple of surprises in there. I recommend it, especially if you're a grinding maniac who wants to get to level 999 and collect every item, you'll get a lot of hours of entertainment for the price while rarely getting bored.

I have to say that this game's title did catch my eye, to be honest if it had not been on sale, I do now know if I would have discovered such a magnificent game. The screenshots this product had, did not please me, as it didn't show much in my opinion, so when going to youtube. I just watched the intro of the game, and Fang, the main protagonist, hooked me into buying it with his attitude. It was so hilarious i had to check it out for myself.

In doing so, it was the best RPGs I have ever taken the time to play. Without going into much detail, I will let you know the pros and cons of of this game.

PROs:
-Great Battle System
-Hilarious, yet epic and touching storyline.
-Great graphics both in and out of battle.
-Side quests and other missions to collect bonuses

CONs:
-You may need to LVL grind in some areas depending how often you avoid battles.
-There could be more areas to explore and make the game longer, but there aren't
-SOME but not all, side quests are too tough and require a ton of searching.

But overall, if you are a fan of Final Fantasy or any other RPG and have time for a couple of laughs and like having a good time, this game is the right one for you! Please! By all means, pick up this game!

Has what any otaku would hope to have in a turn based rpg from Idea Factory. The weird story is what we eat up no matter how obsure. If you liked Hyperdimention Neptunia or Trinity Universe, this is more of that.

Although it plays slightly differently than its relative HyperDimension Neptunia, Fairy Fencer F has a lot of the fun and goofy quirkiness that you'd come to expect from the companies involved with the game. However unlike the HyperDimension series Fairy Fencer F takes on a slightly more serious approach to their story. The game's combat is a bit repetitive and that's the only complaint I have with the game (its combat system is quite similar to that of the HyperDimension series), however what really drew me in to this game are the whacky characters, particularly the lazy main character Fang. There are some good laughs to be had here and if you love the HyperDimension series then I can HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to you. If you're not a fan of those games however then honestly you may not like this one either, unless it was the characters in HyperDimension that turned you off. Either way, if you're in, then bear those fangs (pun-intended) and JUST DO IT.

Everyone who likes Anime and/or Final Fantasy, won't regret to purchase this game.

column42: which enough to take out boss in one go. It's either an overlook in combat design in term of balancing player's characters or the monsters/bosses design are simply bad. All boss in later game proved to be no challenge which this is where they lose a score in gameplay. To put it simple
column43:
I killed a last boss in one combo with main characters. They really really need to rethink on how to balance this combat experience because other JRPG or RPG never have this kind of problem. If you expect combat to be some kind of challenge then you will definitely disppointed. But if you enjoy killing everything with your overpowered party and don't want to experience any kind of challenge which suppose to be in game then I will not stop you either.

I will give a game combat 3/10; there're many flews in this and they're needed to be improved.

Ok so first of all as you can see from the eyes of the girl in the picture she almost has the same eyes as Nep from Hyperdimension Neptunia. Since I'm been urging to play Hyperdimension Neptunia for awhile now why not try a game that's similar to it? After buying the game, playing it and having almost sleepless nights. I have come to the conclusion that this game is worth the money.

The storyline is good, it has some funny dialogues  (For example if you try to remove a piece of the seal from the so called Bringer of Destruction, you'll get two lovely ladies scolding at you. Not to mention one being a masochist)  and alot of other stuff. I don't wanna spoil anything you'll just have to see it for yourself.

Gameplay is also good, I'm pretty sure most of you have played simple turn based rpgs. Like you just choose the command and it does it. Well this isn't your simple plain old turn based rpg. This one has movements, that's right movements where you can actually move your character and then execute command bla bla bla. I'm pretty sure most of you has (have?) already experienced playing games like these with these kinds of gameplay. Anyway this is just my opinion and I'm not a professional at anything. Oh did I forget to mention that you can change the clothing of your characters? :3

Yes has Japanese voice option. Cast includes a few well known anime VAs.
Music by Nobuo Uematsu, concept art by Yoshitaka Amano. Wow was I surprised when I saw those names in the opening credits.
Tons of fun, addicting gameplay. Doesn't take itself too seriously, good humor typical of anime culture. Random battles let you skip the victory sequence and you can go from encounter start to moving on the map again in about 6 seconds if you're one shotting them(take that PS1 era RPGs). Nice graphics, high framerate.
I'm really glad I picked this up.

Quick edit to add more about one of the above points - this is all around faster moving than is typical of JRPGs I've played until now. Every single combat animation down to basic attacks can be skipped by holding a button, going from world map to town and back again is so quick there's no moment of thoughtful hesitation before I do so, even going into menus and changing stuff doesn't seem to take as long for a screen fade as I'm used to JRPGs taking.

When I got gifted this game, I had about 0 expectations for it. I expected it to be some anime ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that I might find amusing and I was curious about the combat. What it actually ended up being was possibly my GOTY 2015 and that’s not even a joke.

Initially, Fairy Fencer F seems like it’s pretty much stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that gets by on being moderately amusing and has really anime jokes that are tired and obnoxious- a refined woman who’s slightly masochistic, a busty blond who’s too casual about nudity, the same ♥♥♥♥ you’ve rolled your eyes at a thousand times if you like anime. And at the start of the game, the combat’s nothing special either, as like most RPGs it has the terrible habit of not giving you many tools other than “press attack, maybe cast a spell if you’re feeling saucy” for the first hour of the game.

What made me keep playing was the UTTER goofiness of Fairize (a sort of super mode you get) and the music that comes with it. Full Contact starts with the lines METAPHORPHOSIZE YOUR HEART, UNLEASH THE HELL INSIDE and doesn’t get any less ridiculous from there, and every time you Fairize there’s a (skippable, something I was grateful for by hour 20) magical girl transformation cutscene where you impale yourself with your weapon. The other thing was the ridiculousness of the protagonist Fang, who starts off as a lazy hedonist who’s only glimmer of a better nature is agreeing to help his fairy partner when she reveals that she’s lost her memory. The writing is genuinely enjoyable too, although early on is marred by the previously mentioned anime staple “jokes”.

However, it only gets better. The battle system opens up, and while disappointingly I never felt challenged to prove my mastery of the combat system, it was still interesting and engaging to learn and improve at. The game’s one real flaw to me (aside from fanservice, especially with Harley) is it’s just too easy- a flaw that’s only noticeable because the battle system is so good you can feel that there’s room for real challenge outside of “my numbers are higher”. The story and characters meanwhile, skyrocket in quality, with everyone quickly becoming likeable, the main character having a real and noticeable character arc, and the tone seamlessly and naturally escalating in scope and gravity without ever having a jarring “when did the comedy end” moment. Even some of the tired jokes get used in actually funny ways, and the rest fade into the background or simply vanish.

Fairy Fencer F is legitimately a great game, which is the absolute last thing I expected it to be. I highly advise anyone who has any interest in RPGs or anime-y games to pick it up.

Also, it has accessories like in a Tales game, and that’s awesome. They’re also reflected in the transformation cutscene, as are alternate costumes (of which there are very few)

Look at that goofy little plush. Buy this game, seriously, it’s good.

If you like Hyperdimention Neptunia then you will like this game, if you didn't like Neptunia's combat mechanics then this would not be for you. It's a lot, a lot, of conversations that are somewhat amusing, but the game does allow you to skip them if your not into the story and just like the combat or have already played through once and listened to the many hours of story already, it's always nice when games don't force the story on you (specailly when your playing through a game a second time). And the combat is Exactly like Hyperdimintion Neptunia which was an interesting idea, and enjoyable, but could be finiky aiming with controller and a bit less finiky but still finiky with mouse and keyboard.

Story seems like most JRPGs, amussing but pretty bad at the same time, kind of like good bad movies for example the first Mortal Kombat movie was a bad movie but good at the same time because it was that cheesy bad.

All in all if you like JRPGs you will probably like this, but expect to get a bit frustrated trying to aim a conal attack at two enemies every once in a while but otherwise enjoyable combat, expect amusingly bad dialog (and a lot of it), and expect to have to grind in the late game (not certain on that, but most JRPGs end up grindy mid way through).

So I played offline for the most part and it took me about 13 hours to beat the main, but I did just power through the story only ignoring most of the sub-quests. Also I only did one of I think three of four endings.

I'd give this game a 8 outta 10

Pros
-Multiple endings
-Really cool card system that you can level up seperate cards and in return give you special boost/perks
-Nice astetics and move animations as well as combat system(kinda like hyperdimentionNep)
-Item crafting system(armor, healing items, and outfits)
-A pretty decent story, but personally I really liked the cards
-And a Candaidian who's your best friend(if you listen it in english)
-A nice variety of characters

Cons
-The animations do get repetitive
-Without spoiling the story, the game does make you repeat half the ♥♥♥♥ing areas in the main story and make you spend a ♥♥♥♥ ton of money doing so
-Enemy recycling with different colors varying on the difficulty of the area aka being lazy in my opinion
-The music will clip out every now and again

But other than that if was an alright game.

I mostly enjoyed the interatctions between Tiara and Fang. And the side story with Apollonius wasn't bad, but I wish they did more with it. Don't get me started on the weird guy in the animal suit... Story wise the main complaint I had is the way the handled the main town. The conversations with the locals were all pointless and did not really endear you with the story, but personally I felt like I had to read it in case there was some subplot that would show up.... sadly they did not really take advanatage of that and no quests from any of the common characters ever occured.

Gameplay itself is pretty mediocre. Reason I say that is because really pretty much through 95% of the game I was just spamming attack + skip, ferrize + skip, attack + skip. This game definitely did not focus on strategy. Most of the time I got through battles without losing any characters because I just focused on stunning the monsters with combos so I would end up getting the game to trigger the event to get other party members to get a whack in. This even worked on bosses. I would generally advise not to buy the DLC that provides the armors unless you want to have two characters be nearly invulnerable for 60-75% of the storyline game. I'm telling you those armors are way overpowered! Don't get me started on the other DLC's where if you want the stat boost at all your characters are in towels?!?!

Now the one thing I really do have to say was a decent idea for the battlesystem and that was the combos mechanic. It really did let me choose a moveset that I could get the maximum amount of damage. The main problem with the combo system is due to how much time it takes to play thing game (and how much I was spamming skip) I ended up only using the same moveset over and over and ignoring any of the other possibilities because 90% of the time the moveset I chose for the A button worked, so there was no reason to choose any of the other choices. I never really used any magics at all except for healing as it wasted more time than it was worth in most cases.

Lastly the questing system at the bar is seemingly pointless. The amount of griding that is needed is rather sad. The rewards do not even cover the time spent on the task in many cases. Once you get to the C important mission I was stuck for a long time because I didn't check to see if there was a way to synth the ingredient.. figured I would pick it up somewhere.... wrong.

Bottom line I would rate the game as a C

Story C+
Gameplay D
Amount of Gameplay A-

If you're bored I would recommend it, but there are better choices out there such as Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky

It's a fun game.  But I find that it challenges your suspension of disbelief.  As you continue playing it, you start to realize that the story can dissociate drastically from the gameplay.

For instance...on the first playthrough, I one-shot a boss.  Cue the upcoming visual novel cutscene where the characters are wincing in pain and groaning about how strong the boss is.  I reaaally didn't get that impression.

So my suggestion is that if you get the game...play the game and follow the story.  But don't play the game AND follow the story.  Treat the two separately, and I think you'll find that it's entertaining as a game and tells a fairly interesting story.  But if you treat the two as one unit, expect to lose some brain cells when the gameplay and story start hand-waving.

This game is a bit weird.  In an era of RPGs where you're able to allocate your stats as you see fit, this game sort of falls back to the traditional method of level-up = auto-allocate stats.  Granted, there is a way to boost your attack stats, but I dearly wish I could up my characters speed / accuracy.  Speed because I'd like to give a certain character in the party the ability to attack first.  Accuracy because there are certain attacks in the game that give 300% damage, but they miss really often.

It turns out that it's not so much that they miss often but that the enemy has an easy time dodging them.  I figured this out when I used these techniques on low level enemies...whereas I would have a 20% hit rate on equivalent level opponents, At level 55, I had a 100% hit rate on level 30 mobs.

The only way to boost the speed and hit rate is to complete a set of challenges.  These require you to do weird things like jump around as the leader of the party or send the enemy flying so you can use interception attacks.  They wouldn't be so bad ordinarily, but I do have complaints about jumping 5000 times per character just to max out the challenge.

Personally, I liked playing this game a lot.  I just wish that I managed to get the Eryn ending first try.  I don't know what I did wrong to get the Tiara ending.

Oh yeah, I suggest turning on Japanese voices occasionally.  You'll find that all sorts of things are voiced that aren't in the English Dub.  For instance, the Fury Fairies.

I bought the came out of boredom. Didn't think I'd like it this much. I find that this game can definately pull you in if your into rpgs otherwise you wouldn't be reading reviews. Also the time on record I put in was literally in two days since I just couldn't put it down. Now go out there buy this get some laughs and enjoy the game.

For people who liked Hyper Dimension Neptunia, this is a must buy . To be fair, I've had my playthroughs of final fantasy and other rpgs, so to me, this turned to be more interactive and strategic than most . There's plenty I like about the game, but a few others I dislike. I'll start with what I like :D

Positive
- Funny, not too many games that introduce a humorous cast of characters actually make me smile and laugh.
- Beautiful art style and anime, characters look and act how they were made
- Easy combat system, items, attack, combos and spells pretty generic but very satisfying to see those combo strings and multiple damage hits
- Basic but fair storyline, very generic and simplistic story to follow and understand

Negatives
- Rushed, many of the characters are thrown into your way and then into your party about 2 minutes after you meet them without even really understanding why or who the hell they are
- Repetative; its a very simple system: go to town, events, buy info, free swords, go into dungeon, grind/complete quests (repeat) the side quests and events are really the only thing besides the storyline you can do
- Very short dungeons (also a pro) The dungeons are usually consisted of less than 5 areas, you can complete the main quest in a matter of minutes
- Protagonist (also a pro) I may get anime people jumping on back for this lol: the protagonist made me laugh and he does grow and develop throughout the game, but its just a hero I cannot get behind and makes me strongly dislike him later in the story. The early part had me laughing, but later on had me facepalming, honestly I wished  Sherman was the main protagonist, thats my opinion though lol.
- Brief tutorials, while most people generically know what their doing; its a little bit of a slap in the face that Eryn's tutorials pop up for like 3 screens going , yeah this is how you do this and this

I will keep this short because I don't want to spoil too much of the story and it should be pretty obvious what kind of game this is, otherwise look it up on YouTube.

The game is part visual novel, part walking around dungeons and battling and part doing side quests. The battle system is somewhat similar to the Hyperdimension Neptunia series, and there are lots and lots of skills and battle points and other elements that you can advance in to get stronger in the way you like. Depending on the play style, it might be necessary to grind a few times, but nothing to write home about.

I had so much fun with this title, it is unreal. I loved the art, I loved the characters and their dialogues. The battle system is fun, but it shouldn't be the only thing to care about. I was mostly interested in advancing the story and enjoying all the adventures and dialogues between the characters. They weren't always in agreement but as the story progresses you don't want to ever lose any of them, even those who may have tried to kill you before.

All in all, especially if you like JRPGs or Anime, I would recommend Fairy Fencer F from the bottom of my heart ♥

reviewText: Like, it was pretty fun until the Canadian guy showed up. He really is the selling point of this game. Made playing the English dub worth it.

The combat mechanics have a bunch of aspects and styles you could work toward, but most of them aren’t needed or worth it: a bunch of underpowered magic you’ll never need, a bunch of fury power-ups you’ll never use, extra weapon styles you don’t need, quest leveling for money you don’t need, synthesizing crap equipment and armour upgrades you don’t need. So many extra things, but in reality, the normal weapon+combos+atk and a few mid-range special moves are everything you need.

I only leveled to mid-30s, but the last bosses were probably slightly too easy, so don’t level past there if you want to keep it challenging. If you complete the furies you’ll be way over-powered!

But I was glad I didn’t have to grind much. There are mechanisms to add abilities to gain exp out of party and more rapidly, so I didn’t find myself grinding for exp or gold. You’ll go to a new area and almost immediately gain 4 levels by the time you reach the boss just fighting the normal spawned monsters. I did have to grind a little for WP (power ups) in an area that gave more of it, but I ended up wasting it on character magic or moves that were more under-powered than what they already had..

Overall a fun and short JRPG. My only gripe would be the crap dialogue. It’s full of trite cursing that detracted from the overall story. It’s pretty hard to root for the protagonist when he’s calling women a b**** in every other scene—this is not an exaggeration. I don’t mind language, but it doesn’t even flow, like a child who just discovered a new /bad word/. Eventually I got the feeling the game developers are clueless how to write diaglogue—you can hire specific people to do that BTW. By Act II it’s much better, but it’s worth mentioning if you have children playing the game. The diaglogue exchanges would probably cause PTA moms to Fairize.

I'm kind of a hard core RPG player and just like anyone who plays RPGs I always have my skepticisms about a game I pick up. Being an enthusiast about Anime didn't have anything to do with my review. I will say that this game is incredibly detailed. The developement of the characters was meticulously thought through and the interactions of the characters don't change for the sake of story developement. All characters are very different and very in personality. The idea of time and it's affect on the world when the particular sequence appears is actually quite accurate. Any change in a timeline can have the potential to change everything about the time stream that you currently travel which is why I believe it was a well thought out paradigm of the story. With the inclusion of the choice of Good or Evil makes this an interesting blend and includes several even more interesting character interations. Players don't necessarily have to grind to finish the game, but it does certainly help. The idea of overkilling enemies has always been a thing for me and with the DLC added to the game, adds the possibility of total annihilation. Getting certain materials to create new weapons, armor, items, misc. items, and other synthesis materials is difficult but if it were easy then it wouldn't be worth the effort. The synthesis items are much stronger than what you can buy and If you farm the materials then it is worth that much more. I would say to be careful about the boss battles when reviving the God or Goddess. If you have the DLC it is easier than normal, however once you reach a certain rank they will start getting though your armor so don't rely on the DLC to last you the whole game. It wont. Overall I recommend this game to any and all RPG enthusiasts out there even if you don't like Anime. It is a rich story full of spontanious and often hilarious conversations. I enjoy the game and I hope anyone who has just gotten or even just thinking about getting it will too.

Though a bit cliche, Fairy Fencer F has its plus points. If you enjoyed games like Neptunia of Mugen Souls, then you won't need to read reviews to see if it will be worth it. Just watch some gameplay and you'll know if you want to.\n\nThe game features a Fairy Link system, giving you more personality in your custimization of your character(s). If you want to have a tank, mage or maybe a strong damage per turn. The only real walking you'll be doing is in dungeons, so you don't have to sidetrack the towns in order to go everywhere before heading out. The final part that the game offers is its Gods Revival" option. By using existing Fairies you can upgrade them once with a unique ability and World Creation stats used to powerup and powerdown your dungeon experience. These mechanics make for a unique experience
date:
but offers only so much.

But what's good about the game?
It has some great soundtrack to accompany you through your experience. Every type of dungeon has its own unique BGM and you are welcomed with more than 1 battle track. The game is also easy to understand. The battle mechanic isn't hard to figure out
recommended: but unlike Final Fantasy X; which uses the same Turn Order for battles
hoursPlayed:
there is little to take advantage of. The story is lovable and you get to enjoy many faces that develop (sort of) over the course of the game. It also takes advantage of the "cliches" of games. The side events are also very Japanese with their slapstick and airheadness and ecchi.

And what's bad about the game?
Like mentioned often it suffers from cliches. If you know a bit of gaming you'll be able to foresee certain events. The game also features a cast of 6/7 to 9 playable characters. If you are going for completion you'll use 2 of those at any given time meaning you have 1 spare seat left. The game also suffers from the lack of difficulty. You can get behind big time
voteText: but you can train yourself back in the game
helpfulPercent: but once you get ahead by a lot you'll breeze through the game with little to no difficulty. New Game+ also leaves you with EVERYTHING so it will be even easier. The game also features a huge world map that won't be used in any way and instead of more dungeons you'll get to play every dungeon twice
votesHelpful: thrice or even four times. The battle music will also get on your nerves since they aren't memorable.\nLastly the biggest flaw for the game is its shortness and cryptic level. If you go for a straight playthrough you can beat it in 15 hours
votesTotal: no problem. If you want to go for 100% you'll have to consult a walkthrough because the game is not going to tell you anything about any unlockable or (hidden) items. The game has a lot of missables and I mean a lot
votesFunny: you'll probably end up playing the game twice or thrice to get everything + the 3 endings.\n\nBy the end if you read it you'll notice more bad things than good things
commentsCount: but that's because bad things stay with you better. I had a good time by the end of the game. The flaws are noticeable and could have been removed
column16: but it's not hindering your experience. All by all I think it's still pretty fun to play. It's not New Game+ worthy though. The final verdict: It's just fun

If you're a gamer that is into the JRPG genre, turn-based battling, visual novels, beautifully drawn anime and background art and hours on end of quests, leveling, skill customization and fairies then Fairy Fencer F is for you. I can't remember the last time I power played an RPG as thoroughly as this one.

I have gone through two playthroughs already and going for a third to get my last ending. Japanese and English voice acticing are amazingly done, though if you choose to hear the game in Japanese you will be treated to some extra voiced content when viewing some Sub-Events back in town. While the game is not punishingly difficult and never posing much of a challenge with the main storyline, there is a degree of challenge present in the sidequests to keep things from being a boring button masher.

Word of advice to completionists not wanting to miss anything on their first playthrough, upon entering a new dungeon and viewing the cutscene, leave immediately and go back to town and accept Lola's quests as they are time sensitive. Try to fight every enemy you see at least once, inspect the maps throroughly to look out for diamonds containing possibly missable loot and obtain the Item Sonar ability as soon as you can.

Overall I recommend this game highly to any JRPG fan that is into a good story filled with likeable characters with a great balance of drama, action and comedy.
